Sec. 26-63. - Project phasing. 
(a)  Purpose. Towns, villages, and hamlets that are developed over a long period of time may be separated into multiple development phases. As market conditions change, the development's product mix may need to change also. On the other hand, certain aspects of the development's relationship to the city need to remain consistent with the approved plan. 
(b)  For each phase of development, the applicant shall provide an accounting of the development rights and obligations applied in that phase and those reserved for future phases, including 
(1)  The amount of land in each phase. 
(2)  The amount of entitlements used - residential units, commercial space, open space. 
(3)  The amount of land permanently protected, including preservation and civic uses. 
(c)  The following entitlements phasing chart shall appear on all town, village, and hamlet plats: 
Entitlements Phasing Chart 

 
(d)  Some required features of town, village, and hamlet subdivisions might not be planned for phase one of construction. Provision of these features still must be provided before phase one construction begins. The following district-wide information shall be included, or updated when previously provided, with the phase one application and each subsequent phase: 
(1)  Site analysis for the entire site. 
(2)  Identification of primary conservation areas. Secondary conservation areas for future phases do not need to be included. 
(3)  Major thoroughfare plan, demonstrating overall site circulation. Neighborhood streets for future phases do not need to be included. 
(4)  Connections to the city's thoroughfare network. 
(5)  Connections to the city and/or regional path system. 
(6)  Transit station site and transit corridor link to South Fulton Parkway corridor (if required). 
(7)  Demonstration of allowance for full infrastructure capacity at buildout. This is an accounting to demonstrate that sufficient land area has been reserved for all necessary stormwater infiltration, wastewater treatment (if applicable), and any other infrastructure requirement dependent on development of future phases. 
(Ord. No. 15-05-138, § 5.11, 5-5-2015) 
Secs. 26-64—26-84. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - SUBDIVISIONS 

Sec. 26-85. - Subdivision improvement guarantees. 
(a)  In order to protect the city and prospective purchasers of and residents in a subdivision, the subdivider/developer shall provide to the city financial security to guarantee the installation of public improvements. The financial security shall be an amount equal to 125 percent of the cost of improvements not in compliance. 
(b)  The subdivider's or developer's financial guarantee may be any of the following: 
(1)  An escrow of funds with the city; 
(2)  An escrow with a bank or savings and loan association upon which the city can draw; 
(3)  An irrevocable letter of commitment or credit upon which the city can draw; 
(4)  A performance bond for the benefit of the city upon which the city can collect, or a certificate of deposit with assignment letter; and 
(5)  Any other form of guarantee approved by the city council that will satisfy the objectives of this section. The guarantee shall be in an amount to secure the full costs, as determined by the city, of constructing or installing the improvements and utilities required. 
(Ord. No. 15-05-138, § 6.1, 5-5-2015) 
Sec. 26-86. - Limitations on minor subdivisions. 
(a)  Purpose. Minor subdivisions provide certain advantages, such as a shorter application process and less public scrutiny, that tend to favor their use over the filing of major subdivision applications. Given these advantages, the prospect exists that subdividers may seek to divide a parcel via consecutive minor subdivisions instead of filing for a major subdivision. It is the intent of the city council to prohibit the practice of "chain" subdivisions where a parcel divided or created by minor subdivision or major subdivision is further subdivided by the minor subdivision process. Therefore, no parcel subdivided after adoption of this chapter may be subsequently divided by the minor subdivision process. 
(b)  Limitations. Land within a minor subdivision shall not be further divided unless a preliminary plat application is filed and approved as a major subdivision pursuant to the requirements of this chapter. 
(c)  RL district. For the division of land in the RL (rural) zoning district, the following rules shall apply: 
(1)  Each proposed lot shall contain a minimum area of three acres. 
(2)  Each proposed subdivision shall have no more than one curb cut per every 1,000 linear feet of thoroughfare frontage. Individual lots shall derive access through shared drives. Gravel drives are permitted. 
(3)  Mailboxes shall be clustered at the drive entrance and all thoroughfare address numbers shall be posted, in order, on a sign at the entrance. When access to a lot may be derived through more than one entrance, address number posting is required only at the entrance most efficient for emergency vehicle access to that lot. 
(4)  The subdivision plat recorded with Fulton County clerk of superior court shall contain the following: 
"This Property may not be further subdivided using the Minor Subdivision process." 
This language shall be included whether or not the plat contains minor subdivision lots. 
(Ord. No. 15-05-138, § 6.2, 5-5-2015) 
Sec. 26-87. - Major subdivision process. 
The following steps are required for the subdivision of land, except subdivisions that qualify for the minor subdivision process: 
(1)  Pre-application meeting. Applications for subdivision review shall not be accepted by the city unless a pre-application meeting has been held with the director. 
(2)  Concept plan. The applicant may submit a concept plan subsequent to the pre-application meeting. 
(3)  Preliminary plat. Upon approval of the concept plan, a preliminary plat may be submitted according to the requirements of this chapter. 
(4)  Development permit/land disturbance permit/construction plans. Upon approval of the preliminary plat, application for development permitting may begin. 
(5)  Final plat. Once the final plat is approved, signed, and recorded with the clerk of superior court, the developer may sell lots. 
(Ord. No. 15-05-138, § 6.3, 5-5-2015) 
Sec. 26-88. - Subdivision design. 
(a)  The director shall have the right to encourage design of the subdivision in a manner that will: 
(1)  Enhance traffic circulation and other community needs; 
(2)  Encourage pedestrian traffic to schools, parks, existing and planned greenspace corridors, and neighborhood shopping centers; 
(3)  Reduce impacts on streams and lakes; 
(4)  Reduce unwanted noise, lights on neighboring lots; and 
(5)  Discourage vehicular speeding on local streets. 
(b)  Town, village, and hamlet subdivision design process. 
(1)  The design of towns, villages, and hamlets is guided by two organizing principles: the preservation and integration of existing site features, and the concept of the pedestrian shed. The site analysis is a critical early step in the subdivision process. The site analysis will reveal which land is appropriate for preservation, which is most likely to be agriculturally productive, where physical obstacles to development are located, and the location of unique or otherwise notable features of natural, cultural, or historical value. This process will guide the designation of open space and the alignment of new thoroughfares, and it will identify features that, if incorporated as focal points of the neighborhoods, will add value to the development. 
(2)  Notable site features should form the basis of civic areas and neighborhood centers. Then residential, commercial, and civic areas should be arranged in pedestrian sheds around them. The pedestrian shed represents the physical limits most Americans will walk before choosing to drive. The city's comprehensive plan defines a variety of development forms that are compact, walkable, mixed-use, and ecologically sustainable. Towns, villages, and mixed-use hamlets allow a mix of uses so their residents and customers do not have to drive everywhere. A hamlet may be comprised of a partial or entire pedestrian shed (one-fourth-mile radius) or more than one pedestrian shed. Villages and towns shall be designed and developed as multiple pedestrian sheds. Residential neighborhoods in mixed-use districts and residential hamlets should be organized as pedestrian sheds around playgrounds, parks, civic spaces, commercial nodes, and/or notable site features. 
(3)  Hamlet, village, and town planning process applications shall demonstrate adherence to the following standard planning protocol: 
a.  Step 1. Map existing site resources. 
1.  Identify primary and secondary conservation areas, identify unique features, and analyze soils and slopes to delineate open space. 
2.  Identify and delineate paths, roads, ponds, woods, streams, slopes and wetlands. 
3.  Design the parks, squares, or greens around ponds, wooded areas, specimen trees, or other unique features as much as practicable. 
4.  Define natural boundaries on the site excluding arterials, utility easements, steep slopes (those exceeding 35 percent in 5,000 square feet contiguous areas) and any area of land to be preserved for its natural use. 
b.  Step 2. Identify open space locations for permanent protection. Incorporate notable site features. Plan for resident access. 
c.  Step 3. Locate the commercial center on thoroughfare or intersection with highest traffic. 
d.  Step 4. Structure site into pedestrian sheds. 
1.  Pedestrian sheds form the basis of mixed-use developments. The size and shape of the neighborhood is determined by the pattern of the pedestrian shed. 
2.  Pedestrian shed is equivalent to a five minute walk from edge to center. 
3.  One pedestrian shed should be centered upon the commercial center. 
4.  Additional sheds should cover the remainder of the site with substantial overlap to prevent dilution of each center as a viable mixed use center. 
5.  Can use irregular shape to represent actual walk times. 
e.  Step 5. Adjust pedestrian sheds locations on site. 
1.  Centers of the pedestrian shed must coincide in with natural or manmade features on the site. Site designers should use the features in the landscape as the backbone for public spaces. Examples: 
(i)  Cluster of specimen trees can become a green, park or square. 
(ii)  A hedgerow may present the opportunity to become a tree lined street or avenue. 
(iii)  Existing paths on site can determine the location of streets and roads. 
2.  Where such natural features either do not exist or do not provide such opportunities for becoming public space, introduce a public civic space as the center of each pedestrian shed. 
f.  Step 6. Design street and path network. Connect centers with thoroughfares. 
1.  Subsequent to this point in the design of the district, the natural features have been delineated and designed into the neighborhood design, the main commercial area has been determined and the pedestrian sheds have been outlined. 
2.  Connect the centers with one another by "main" streets or avenues. They should be direct approaches but not necessarily straight. Using the terrain of the site to deflect and slow traffic through the neighborhood. Include pedestrian, equestrian, and bicycle access to centers, civic sites, open space features, and other amenities. 
3.  Fill in the areas between the main streets with streets, roads, and paths into a network. Adjust the network to create a pattern of blocks. Such blocks should be smaller when in close proximity to the centers, and larger in the edges. 
4.  Subdivide the blocks into lots. 
g.  Step 7. Detail other neighborhood elements. 
h.  Step 8. Reserve civic sites. 
i.  Step 9. Determine uses of open space network and develop an open space management plan. 
j.  Step 10. Provide covenants, easements, and establish local governance. 
(Ord. No. 15-05-138, § 6.4, 5-5-2015) 
Sec. 26-89. - Farmette subdivisions. 
(a)  Description. A farmette is a large-lot residential subdivision of rural land. From each original lot of record, a maximum of three minor subdivision lots, each with a minimum size of three acres, may be created. Then, additional lots with a minimum size of 20 acres may be created from the balance of the property. 
(b)  Design. 
(1)  Farmette lots are a minimum of 20 acres, however up to three minor subdivision lots may be created on any lot of record at the beginning of the farmette subdivision process. 
(2)  Once the base farmette lots are established, lot lines may be moved to increase the size of one or more minor subdivision lots in the same original parcel while reducing the size of one or more farmette lots. No additional lots may be created by this method and no farmette lot may be reduced to a size smaller than the average lot size created from the same original parcel. The size of a farmette lot also may not be increased in this process. 
(3)  Newly-created farmette subdivision lots shall derive access via new subdivision thoroughfares or shared drives on access easements. Unpaved roads or drives are allowed. Access easements for shared drives must be provided and shall be submitted to the director at the time of plat approval. 
(4)  Farmette subdivisions shall have no more than one entrance per 1,000 feet of road frontage. The director may require a 20-foot no-access easement and planting strip along the thoroughfare to ensure that lots fronting on the thoroughfare do not have access thereto. Mailboxes shall be clustered at the entrance unless a new thoroughfare is created, allowing mailboxes to be located adjacent to individual lots. The U.S. Postal Service may require a location for a common delivery box at the entrance to the subdivision. 
(5)  Farmette subdivisions shall be buffered according to chapter 35, zoning. 
(c)  Process. Farmette subdivisions may be created by following the minor subdivision procedures. 
(Ord. No. 15-05-138, § 6.5, 5-5-2015) 
Sec. 26-90. - Property owners association. 
(a)  A property owners association, homeowners association, or equivalent body shall be established in all HM, VL, and TN districts. 
(b)  The association shall be responsible for services and maintenance as described herein. 
(c)  The association shall annually assess each property owner an amount sufficient to maintain and replace infrastructure, as necessary. 
(d)  The association shall provide a bond, escrow, or other surety to the city in the amount determined by the city engineer to guarantee the repair, maintenance, operation and management of all private roads, stormwater infrastructure, shared wastewater infrastructure, and designated open space. 
(e)  The association shall be responsible for all repair, maintenance, operation, and management of private roads, stormwater infrastructure, shared wastewater infrastructure, and designated open space, unless an agreement providing for such services by a third party has been filed with and approved by the director. This shall not limit the association from contracting for those services at will while retaining final responsibility for their provision. 
(f)  Failure to adequately manage, operate, or maintain the wastewater or stormwater systems may result in the city assessing a special tax on association members to cover the costs of correcting the problem. 
(g)  If the city council determines that the association is not capable of preventing a catastrophic failure of critical infrastructure under its control, the city may take over the management, operation, maintenance or repair of the system and levy a special assessment on the members of the association. 
(Ord. No. 15-05-138, § 6.6, 5-5-2015) 
Secs. 26-91—26-108. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - THOROUGHFARES 

Sec. 26-109. - General requirements. 
(a)  All thoroughfares shall be appropriate to the proposed density, building height, and uses, as defined in the zoning ordinance. 
(b)  Thoroughfares shall be designed in context with the physical form and desired design speed of the neighborhood or development style through which they pass. The public frontages of thoroughfares that pass from one neighborhood or development style to another should be adjusted accordingly. Thoroughfares shall be designed and constructed with a coordinated program of landscaping and pavement or other surface treatment. 
(c)  All thoroughfares shall terminate at other thoroughfares, forming a network. Thoroughfares shall be interconnected, affording easier, safer access for emergency vehicles, school buses, and sanitation trucks while distributing traffic more evenly and avoiding excess traffic on certain central residential thoroughfares. 
(d)  Thoroughfare patterns that result in isolated pockets of development with relatively little interconnectivity are strongly discouraged. 
(e)  Thoroughfares shall follow existing contours with a minimum of cut and fill and shall be designed for interparcel access. 
(f)  All newly created lots shall derive access from internal subdivision thoroughfares. 
(g)  All subdivisions shall provide thoroughfare interconnectivity with adjacent properties where possible. 
(h)  Thoroughfares shall reduce impacts on streams and lakes, reduce unwanted noise, lights on neighboring lots; and discourage vehicular speeding on thoroughfares with residential uses. 
(i)  All thoroughfare terminations shall receive special attention in the plan and shall be identified as locations for features such as civic sites, public art, monuments, scenic views, architectural articulation of buildings, or structures of a type and character that respond visually to the location, as approved by the director. 
(Ord. No. 15-05-138, § 7.1, 5-5-2015) 
Sec. 26-110. - Thoroughfare infrastructure. 
(a)  Alignment. 
(1)  Thoroughfare alignment, intersections and jogs. Thoroughfares shall be aligned to join with planned or existing thoroughfares. When a thoroughfare intersection is less than 75 degrees, a roundabout intersection type shall be constructed. Thoroughfares shall enter and exit roundabouts at angles of 75 degrees or greater. Where thoroughfare offsets or jogs cannot be avoided, offset T-intersections shall be separated by a minimum centerline offset of 150 feet in non-rural areas and 300 feet in rural areas (see figure). Roundabouts should be considered as an alternative solution to such offset problems. 

(2)  Strategically located T-intersections, jogs and offsets that interrupt the visual axis of the street are encouraged. The lots that terminate these vistas are recommended locations for landmark features. That is, buildings or other features of architectural, civic, cultural or historical importance. They can provide closure to urban spaces, aids to navigation, and can designate transitions between neighborhoods. Greater care should be taken with the design of these sites. 
(3)  Continuation of existing thoroughfares and connections. Existing thoroughfares, and their rights-of-way, shall be continued at the same or greater width, but in no case less than the required width. The planning commission may require that a major subdivision provide one or more future connections to adjoining subdivisions or unsubdivided tracts. 
(4)  Intersections regulated by traffic signals are discouraged. A street network design that distributes the traffic load is preferred. The use of roundabouts is encouraged where traffic counts are high. When signals cannot be avoided, as in a dense business district street grid, the signals shall be coordinated and timed and the signal controllers shall be able to accommodate remote operation. 
(5)  Thoroughfare plans for future phases of the tract. Where the plat or site plan proposed to be subdivided or developed includes only part of the tract owned or intended for subdivision or development by the subdivider or land developer, a tentative plan of a future thoroughfare system for the portion not slated for immediate subdivision consideration may be required by the director and, if required, shall be prepared and submitted by the subdivider or land developer. 
(6)  Marginal access thoroughfares. Whenever a major subdivision is proposed abutting the right-of-way of a U.S. or state highway, a marginal access thoroughfare approximately parallel and adjacent to such right-of-way may be required at a distance suitable for the appropriate use of land between such marginal access thoroughfare and highway right-of-way. The city may also require a 20-foot no-access easement and planting strip along the highway or boulevard thoroughfare to ensure that lots fronting on said thoroughfare do not have access thereto. (See Figure.) 

(b)  Visibility. 
(1)  Minimum vertical. All local roads with 25 m.p.h. designs shall be connected by vertical crest curves of a minimum length not less than 12 times the algebraic difference between the rates of grade, expressed in feet per hundred. All local roads with a 25 m.p.h. design speed shall be connected by vertical sag curves of minimum length not less than 26 times the algebraic difference between the rates of grade, expressed in feet per hundred. In any case, the sight distance shall meet the minimum requirements of this article. 
a.  In proposed approaches of new streets to intersections with existing streets, there shall be a suitable leveling of the street at a grade not exceeding three percent and for a distance of not less than 50 feet as measured from the back of the curb of the intersecting street. 
b.  In approaches to intersections internal to residential subdivisions, there shall be a suitable leveling of the street at a grade not exceeding five percent and for a distance of not less than 50 feet as measured from the center point of the intersection. 
(2)  Minimum horizontal. Radii of centerline curvature: 
a.  Street designed for 35 m.p.h.: 200 feet. 
b.  Other streets: 100 feet. 
(3)  Tangents. Between reverse curves, there shall be not less than the following minimum tangents: 
a.  Streets designed for 35 m.p.h.: 100 feet. 
b.  Other streets: 50 feet. 
(4)  Intersection visibility requirements. Roadways and their intersections shall be designed such that proper sight distance is maintained. Minimum sight distance shall be determined by the operating speed of the road as determined by the department of public works. Intersection sight distance shall be no less than the following: 
280 feet for 25 m.p.h. 
335 feet for 30 m.p.h. 
390 feet for 35 m.p.h. 
445 feet for 40 m.p.h. 
500 feet for 45 m.p.h. 
610 feet for 55 m.p.h. 
a.  Minimum horizontal visibility shall be measured on centerline. 
b.  When a proposed curb cut intersects an existing roadway, the minimum visibility shall be provided as follows: 
1.  When measuring in the horizontal plane, intersection sight distance is determined with the following assumptions. The driver's eye location is to be assumed at the center line of the exiting lane of the proposed curb cut behind the stop bar. The object location is to be assumed at the centerline of the closest oncoming lane for each direction. 
2.  When measuring in the vertical plane, intersection sight distance is determined with an assumed height of driver's eye and an assumed height of object of 3.5 feet. 
3.  When measuring in either plane, the line of sight must remain in the proposed dedicated right-of-way, unless sufficient easements, maintenance agreements, indemnification agreements are provided, or additional right-of-way is dedicated. 
(5)  Stopping sight distance visibility requirements. Roadways and their intersections shall be designed such that proper stopping sight distance is maintained. Minimum sight distance shall be determined by the design speed of the proposed road as determined by the department of public works. Stopping sight distance along a roadway shall be no less than the following: 
155 feet for 25 m.p.h. 
200 feet for 30 m.p.h. 
250 feet for 35 m.p.h. 
a.  Minimum vertical visibility for stopping sight distance along the roadway shall be determined by measuring between two points of which the height of the driver's eye shall be assumed at 3.5 feet to an assumed object which is two feet in height. The line of sight must remain within the proposed dedicated right-of-way, unless sufficient easements, maintenance agreements, and indemnification agreements are provided, or additional right-of-way is dedicated. 
b.  Minimum horizontal visibility for stopping sight distance shall be measured on centerline. 
(6)  Sight visibility triangle. At the intersection of a thoroughfare and a driveway or the intersection of two thoroughfares, a triangle defined by the first 20 feet of property line along the thoroughfare or driveway beginning at the intersection of such property lines shall be kept free of visual obstructions greater than three feet in height. The director may adjust these standards where topography or other conditions pose challenges to visibility that require more stringent requirements. 
(c)  Infrastructure specifications. 
(1)  Grading and stabilization of thoroughfare rights-of-way. When a new public thoroughfare is proposed, all trees, brush, stumps, rocks, or other debris shall be cleared from the thoroughfare right-of-way, except in cases where trees are required to be preserved by the city arborist or by the approved plans. All thoroughfares shall be graded to lines, grades and cross sections approved on plans. All unsurfaced, disturbed portions of thoroughfare rights-of-way shall be stabilized by seeding, fertilizing, and mulching or by another equally effective method as approved by the director. 
(2)  Thoroughfare grades. No thoroughfare grade shall be less than one percent. No thoroughfare grade for a highway or boulevard thoroughfare shall exceed eight percent. No other thoroughfare grade shall exceed 12 percent, unless the director finds that due to topographic conditions, a steeper grade is necessary, in which case the thoroughfare grade shall not exceed 16 percent. Grades between 12 percent and 16 percent shall not exceed a length of 180 feet. No unpaved thoroughfare grade shall exceed eight percent. 
(3)  Bridges. Bridges on public rights-of-way shall meet current American Association of State Highway and Transportation Officials standards. 
(4)  Dead-end thoroughfares and cul-de-sacs. 
a.  Cul-de-sac thoroughfares shall be prohibited except when they are stubbed out for future connections or as approved by the director. The maximum length of such thoroughfares shall be 600 feet in non-rural areas and 1,200 feet in rural areas. Street extensions that stub out to provide future connection through protected open space and do not serve any lots shall not be included in these measurements. No cul-de-sac shall serve more than ten lots. 
b.  Thoroughfares that are planned to continue at some future date may provide a temporary cul-de-sac with adequate turn around facilities as required by the director. 
c.  Wherever cul-de-sacs or hammerhead turnarounds are unavoidable (typically for topographic reasons) they must always be provided with bicycle or pedestrian linkages to other nearby thoroughfares or to a neighborhood trail system. 
(5)  Blocks specific to all non-rural areas. 
a.  The maximum length for a block is 600 linear feet with the total perimeter length not to exceed 1,680 linear feet and the total area of a block shall not exceed 3.30 acres. 
b.  Any block face exceeding 600 linear feet shall include a dedicated thoroughfare or open space providing through-vehicular and/or pedestrian access. 
(Ord. No. 15-05-138, § 7.2, 5-5-2015) 
Sec. 26-111. - Thoroughfare types and design. 
(a)  Herein are established permissible thoroughfare types: 
(1)  Rear alley (RA). A vehicular way located to the rear of lots providing access to service areas, parking, and outbuildings and containing utility easements. 
(2)  Road (RD). A local, rural and in some cases non-rural thoroughfare of low-to-moderate vehicular speed and capacity. 
(3)  Street (ST). A local non-rural thoroughfare of low speed and capacity. 
(4)  Commercial street (CS). A non-rural thoroughfare of medium speed and capacity fronted with commercial uses. 
(5)  Avenue (AV) and commercial avenue (CSAV). A non-rural thoroughfare of medium speed and high capacity. A commercial avenue is fronted with commercial uses. 
(6)  Boulevard (BV). A non-rural thoroughfare of medium speeds and high capacity fronted with commercial uses. 
(7)  Highway (HW). A state-designated thoroughfare with high travel speeds and high capacity. Access to a highway requires state DOT review. 
(b)  Herein are established transportation provisions: 
(1)  Bicycle lane (BL). A dedicated lane for cycling within a moderate-speed vehicular thoroughfare, demarcated by striping. 
(2)  Bicycle route (BR). A thoroughfare suitable for the shared use of bicycles and automobiles moving at low speeds. 
(3)  Bicycle trail (BT). A bicycle way running independently of a vehicular thoroughfare. 
(4)  Path (PT). A pedestrian way traversing a park or rural area, with landscape matching the contiguous open space, ideally connecting directly with the urban sidewalk network. 
(c)  Thoroughfares shall be designed as depicted in the following tables. Additional provisions and widths may be permitted as approved by the director.

Table 26-111-5. Thoroughfare Assemblies: Streets

Development Contexts: 
Rural: Traditional rural development style as found in the city's RL district or open space. 
Neighborhood: Low to moderate density, low rise, predominately residential development style. 
Core: the densest development areas in the city. Medium to high rise construction, significant commercial uses, along with multifamily and office buildings.

(Ord. No. 15-05-138, § 7.3, 5-5-2015) 
Sec. 26-112. - Unpaved thoroughfares standards. 
(a)  The unpaved thoroughfares may be approved for road or street thoroughfare types. Commercial streets, avenues, and boulevards shall be paved. 
(b)  The maximum number of lots to be served by an unpaved thoroughfare is 12. 
(c)  Thoroughfares planned to serve commercial uses shall be paved in non-rural areas. This is not to be interpreted to prevent unpaved drives on commercial property. 
(d)  The grade of any unpaved thoroughfare shall not exceed ten percent. 
(e)  All intersections of unpaved thoroughfares with paved thoroughfares require a 20-foot paved apron at the intersection, with a concrete transition strip not less than 12 inches in length where the apron meets the unpaved thoroughfare. 
(f)  When unpaved thoroughfares slope upward from an intersection with a paved thoroughfare, the profile of the unpaved thoroughfare shall flatten to a slope no greater than two percent for a minimum of 20 feet before the apron. 
(Ord. No. 15-05-138, § 7.4, 5-5-2015) 
Sec. 26-113. - Curb cuts and access specifications. 
(a)  Entrance improvement specifications. 
(1)  Roadway entrances and improvements, including necessary acceleration and/or deceleration lanes and right/left turn lanes, shall be designed, installed, and maintained as approved by the state department of transportation, as applicable, or the director, in accordance with applicable state or city specifications. 
(2)  All entrances or exits of any thoroughfare or driveway, public or private, from or to any state highway shall be approved by the state department of transportation and the director prior to the construction of such entrances or exits and prior to the issuance of any land use permit or building permit for any improvement to be served by such entrances or exits. 
(3)  All entrances or exits of any thoroughfare or driveway, public or private, from or to any city thoroughfare shall be approved by the director prior to the construction of such entrances or exits and prior to the issuance of any land use permit or building permit for any improvement to be served by such entrances or exits. 
(4)  When located along highway, boulevard or avenue thoroughfares (see section 26-111), curb cuts are prohibited. 
(b)  The following factors may be considered during the review and approval of a specific location of an entrance: 
(1)  The location of existing or planned median breaks; 
(2)  Separation requirements between the entrance and major intersections; 
(3)  Separation requirements between other entrances; 
(4)  The need to provide shared access with other sites; 
(5)  The need to align with previously approved or constructed access points on the opposite side of the thoroughfare; 
(6)  Lot frontage and access do not necessarily have to be along or front the same public thoroughfare, if approved by the director; and 
(7)  The minimum number of entrances needed to move traffic onto and off of the site safely and efficiently. 
(c)  Access along and near divided highways. Where a divided highway exists or is planned, the following access standards shall be met: 

 
(d)  Curb cut specifications. No curb cut or access driveway shall be permitted to be located closer than 100 feet to the nearest existing or proposed right-of-way of an intersecting thoroughfare. Curb cuts or access driveways shall be no narrower than 22 feet from back of curb to back of curb, or 12 feet in the case of one-way streets when approved by the director. Strict adherence to these requirements may not be practical in all instances as determined by the director. The director may limit the maximum width of a curb cut and/or the number of curb cuts to a parcel as necessary when it is deemed to be of benefit to the safety and welfare of the public. 
(e)  Gates. Gates controlling access to more than one lot shall be prohibited, except in the case of an approved farmette subdivision (see section 26-89). This shall not be interpreted to limit gates controlling access to multiple lots under a single ownership, such as, but not limited to, a multi-parcel farm or a rural homestead. 
(f)  Interparcel connections. 
(1)  New development that contains or is intended to contain more than one building or use on site shall provide connections so that automobile trips between and among such buildings or uses can be accomplished without using the highway or major thoroughfare. Where possible and practical, new developments and substantial improvements to existing developments shall provide for pedestrian and automobile access connections between adjacent properties under different ownership when the uses of the properties are of such compatibility that patrons may frequent both buildings or uses in the same vehicle trip. 
(2)  When land is subdivided, created parcels shall be arranged and designed so as to allow for the opening of future thoroughfares and provide access to those areas not presently served by thoroughfares. Internal subdivision thoroughfare and pedestrian path networks shall connect to the thoroughfare and pedestrian path networks of adjoining subdivisions where possible. Future access to adjoining undeveloped property shall be provided via stub-out thoroughfares and paths. Such access shall be provided at least one per 1,000 feet of perimeter. 
(3)  Where district buffers are required, thoroughfare stub-outs shall extend through the buffer to the property line. When connecting to an existing thoroughfare network in a neighboring subdivision, thoroughfares shall extend laterally through the buffer to connect with existing stub-outs. 
(4)  The subdivider shall submit documentation of the necessary easements providing for access to a public thoroughfare for proposed lots that front only on an existing, documented, paved private thoroughfare or driveway. 
(5)  Alleys are encouraged as a means towards interparcel connectivity. Dead-end alleys shall be avoided where possible; but if unavoidable, they shall be provided with adequate turn-around facilities. Service access shall be provided to nonresidential developments for off-thoroughfare loading, unloading, and parking consistent with and adequate for the uses proposed. 
(Ord. No. 15-05-138, § 7.5, 5-5-2015) 
Sec. 26-114. - Thoroughfare lighting. 
When required, thoroughfare lights shall be provided in accordance with city specifications by the developers of a subdivision prior to the approval of a final plat. Fixtures and standards/poles installed or used shall be approved by the city and by the utility company that will be responsible for the maintenance of the facilities. The fixtures shall be mounted no more than 30 feet above the ground and shall have appropriate arm length or power to place light over the thoroughfare. Post top luminaries may be permitted when approved by the director. Fixtures shall be located no more than 500 feet apart, unless approved by the director, and, when provided, at least one light shall be located at each public or private thoroughfare intersection within the subdivision or land development. 
(1)  Pedestrian lighting shall be provided along all commercial streets (section 26-111). Light posts for pedestrian lighting shall not exceed a height of 15 feet from finished grade. 
(2)  The developer shall pay all costs for poles, fixtures and any other related items or materials necessary for the installation of thoroughfare lights, as well as arrange an agreement with the utility company for complete maintenance of all installations. Along private thoroughfares, the property owner's association may assume the responsibility and make the monthly payments to the power company for electrical energy for each thoroughfare light after 50 percent of the lots in that development phase have been sold. Along public thoroughfares, the city may assume the responsibility and make the monthly payments to the power company for electrical energy for each thoroughfare light only after these requirements have been met and improvements accepted by the governing authority. Maintenance and operation costs of thoroughfare lights will be assumed by the city no earlier than two years after lights have been installed. 
(3)  Lighting standards. 
a.  Cobra, shoebox light fixtures and neon lighting are prohibited. 
b.  Light fixtures shall be designed and located to minimize spillage onto adjoining properties. 
c.  The lighting fixtures of exposed rooftop parking shall be concealed by a parapet wall and shall not be seen from surrounding thoroughfares. 
d.  All lighting must conform to this section and the night sky ordinance in the zoning ordinance. 
e.  Off-site spill. Lighting levels at property lines shall be a maximum measurement as listed: 
1.  RL district: 0.5 footcandles. 
2.  HM districts: 1.0 footcandle. 
3.  VL district: 2.0 footcandles. 
4.  TN district: 2.0 footcandles. 
Table 26-114-1. Thoroughfare Lighting 

Table 26-114-2. Public Darkness 

(Ord. No. 15-05-138, § 7.6, 5-5-2015) 
Sec. 26-115. - Thoroughfare signs. 
(a)  Signs for thoroughfare names, directions of travel, traffic control, and hazards shall be provided as directed by the director. Thoroughfare signs on exterior/boundary thoroughfares shall be installed by the city with the developer paying a proportionate share determined by the city. Thoroughfare signs for interior thoroughfares of a subdivision or land development shall be installed at the subdivider or developer's expense by the subdivider or developer, subject to the approval of the director. 
(b)  Unless otherwise provided in standards and specifications adopted by the city, thoroughfare signs shall meet the following specifications. Signs shall be constructed of aluminum sheets with reflective backgrounds. Information on the thoroughfare name signs shall be readable from both sides of the sign. Signs shall be installed on a steel post or another mounting system as approved by the director. The vertical distance from the thoroughfare elevation to the bottom of the sign face shall be seven feet with a minimum burial depth of three feet. 
(Ord. No. 15-05-138, § 7.7, 5-5-2015) 
Sec. 26-116. - Curbs and gutters. 
(a)  Curbs and gutters shall be installed if required by the director in accordance with standards and specifications of the city. 
(b)  Curbs and gutters are required for all thoroughfares when sidewalks are required by this chapter, except in rural areas. All nonresidential subdivisions and land developments must have curbs and gutters, regardless of the size of the lots. 
(c)  When property fronting on an existing city thoroughfare in non-rural areas is subdivided or developed, and the subdivision or land development uses said existing thoroughfare for access, then curb and gutter shall be required along said thoroughfare along the entire property frontage of said thoroughfare except when lack of curb and gutter is desirable to enhance rural character, as determined by the director. 
(d)  Curbs shall be granite or concrete which shall be class A 3,000 psi strength at 28 days. The typical curb minimum section shall be six inches by 24 inches by 12 inches (see figure.) 

(e)  All thoroughfares not required to include curbs and gutters shall be graded, paved (if applicable), and drained to meet all construction and drainage standards for ditches, slopes, and grassing according to specifications established by the city. 
(Ord. No. 15-05-138, § 7.8, 5-5-2015) 
Sec. 26-117. - Sidewalks, landscaping, and amenities. 
(a)  Sidewalks. 
(1)  Sidewalks shall be constructed as specified in section 26-111. 
(2)  Sidewalks shall be required when land developments and subdivisions are located within one mile of a public school. 
(3)  Sidewalks shall be included within the dedicated nonpavement right-of-way of thoroughfares and shall parallel the thoroughfare pavement as much as possible; provided, however, the director may permit or encourage sidewalks to be designed and constructed so that they meander around permanent obstructions or deviate from a linear pattern for design purposes. In areas of dense vegetation or steep slopes, or when more than 800 feet from activity nodes, single side sidewalks, or alternative sidewalk routings away from the thoroughfare, are permissible subject to approval of the director. 
(b)  Landscaping. 
(1)  Thoroughfare trees shall be planted on both sides of all thoroughfares where required per section 26-111. Trees required on public frontages may be permitted to relocate to open spaces when such areas are located within 100 feet from where the trees would otherwise be required 
(2)  Landscape areas shall be provided as defined in section 26-111. Except along greenways, a minimum four-foot-wide landscape area shall be provided along a minimum of one side of all thoroughfares per section 26-111. 
(3)  Street trees shall have a minimum 270 square feet of permeable surface per tree in the rural areas and a minimum 25 square feet of permeable surface and 250 square feet of structural soil per tree in non-rural areas. 
(c)  Amenities. Where provided, lighting, signage, benches, recycling bins, trash receptacles, drinking fountains, and other thoroughfare furniture shall be compatible with the surrounding area in material, color, finish and architectural style. 
(Ord. No. 15-05-138, § 7.9, 5-5-2015) 
Sec. 26-118. - Bicycle and multi-use paths. 
(a)  A bicycle network consisting of bicycle trails, multiuse trails, bicycle routes and bicycle lanes should be provided throughout the community as indicated in Table 26-118-1. The community bicycle network shall be connected to existing or proposed regional networks when such networks exist or are planned within 2,000 feet of the district. The city may require the purchase of an easement to make such connections possible. 
(b)  A multiuse path network constructed to the city's multiuse path standards and connected with proposed and existing path networks in the city. The city may require the purchase of an easement to make such connections possible. Where connections are not possible to existing or planned path networks, the developer shall stub out path terminations at the rate of one per 1,000 feet of district perimeter. No more than 30 percent of the paths within an individual district that make up this network shall be aligned with automobile thoroughfares. 
(c)  Bicycle infrastructure shall also include bicycle parking facilities of the appropriate type and appropriate proximity to uses as indicated in Tables 26-118-2 and 26-118-3, where "short-term" parking serves uses such as retail and service commercial, "day parking" serves employment centers such as office and industrial uses, and "26-hour/overnight parking" serves residential and hospitality uses. 
Table 26-118-1. Bikeway and Facility Type Summary 

Table 26-118-2. Parking Types 

Table 26-118-3. General Location Standards 

(Ord. No. 15-05-138, § 7.10, 5-5-2015) 
Sec. 26-119. - Private thoroughfares. 
(a)  Private thoroughfares permitted. Private thoroughfares may be permitted within subdivisions, subject to the requirements of this section. Applications for approval of private thoroughfares shall be considered by the director at the time of preliminary plat approval. The director may impose conditions on the approval of private thoroughfares to ensure various public safety purposes and to mitigate potential problems with private thoroughfares. No final plat involving a private thoroughfare shall be approved unless said final plat conforms to the requirements of this section. 
(b)  Construction plans required. It shall be unlawful for any person, firm, or corporation to construct a new private thoroughfare or alter an existing private thoroughfare or to cause the same to be done without first obtaining approval of construction plans from the director and a development permit issued in accordance with the requirements of this chapter. 
(c)  Standards. All private thoroughfares shall be constructed to all standards for public thoroughfares as required by this chapter for public thoroughfares, applicable construction specifications of the city, and as approved by the director. 
(d)  Thoroughfare names and signs. Private thoroughfares shall be named, subject to the approval of the director. The subdivider of land involving a private thoroughfare shall install thoroughfare signs containing the thoroughfare name, as approved by the director. The sign signifying the private thoroughfare may be required by the city to be a different color than that of thoroughfare signs provided for public thoroughfares, in order to distinguish maintenance responsibilities in the field. 
(e)  Easements. Easements for private thoroughfares shall be designated on final plats as general-purpose public access and utility easements, along with the name of said private thoroughfare. Said easement shall at minimum be of the same width as that required for the right-of-way of a public thoroughfare by section 26-111, thoroughfare assemblies, for the type of public thoroughfare most closely resembling the proposed private thoroughfare. Easements for private thoroughfares shall not be included in any calculation of minimum lot size or density limitations established by local land use regulations. In the cases of private thoroughfares, the general-purpose public access and utility easement for the private thoroughfare shall either; 
(1)  Be shown in a manner on the final plat such that each lot fronting the private thoroughfare extends to the centerline of the private thoroughfare; no lot shall be permitted to be divided by the general purpose public access and utility easement required and established for a private thoroughfare; or 
(2)  Shall be drawn as its own discrete parcel to be dedicated to a private homeowners association (i.e., not shown to be a part of any lot). 
(f)  Maintenance. The city shall not maintain, repair, resurface, rebuild, or otherwise improve thoroughfares, signs, drainage improvements or any other appurtenances within general purpose public access and utility easements established for private thoroughfares. A private maintenance covenant recorded with the clerk of the superior court of Fulton County shall be required for any private thoroughfare and other improvements within general-purpose public access and utility easements established for private thoroughfares. The covenant shall set out the distribution of expenses, remedies for non-compliance with the terms of the agreement, rights to the use of easements, and other pertinent considerations. The covenant shall specifically include the following terms. 
(1)  The covenant shall establish minimum annual assessments in an amount adequate to defray costs of ordinary maintenance and procedures for approval of additional needed assessments. The covenant shall also specify that the funds from such assessments will be held by a homeowners or property owners association in cases of a subdivision of seven or more lots fronting on a private thoroughfare. 
(2)  The covenant shall include a periodic maintenance schedule. 
(3)  The covenant for maintenance shall be enforceable by any property owner served by the private thoroughfare. 
(4)  The covenant shall establish a formula for assessing maintenance and repair costs equitably to property owners served by the private thoroughfare. 
(5)  The covenant shall run with the land. 
(6)  The city may, at its discretion, as a condition of approving private thoroughfares, require a performance bond and/or maintenance bond be submitted by the subdivider and held by a homeowners or property owners association, or the council may require that the subdivider pay an amount of money as recommended by the director into an escrow account or other suitable account for the maintenance and repair of private thoroughfares and stormwater management improvements, to be drawn from by the homeowners or property owners association as maintenance and repair needs may arise. 
(g)  Specifications for final plats involving private thoroughfares. The director shall not approve for recording any final plat involving a private thoroughfare unless and until it shall contain the following on the face of the plat: 
(1)  Deed book and page reference to the recorded covenant required by this section (a copy of the applicable stamped deed book pages must be supplied with the application). 
WARNING, the City of Chattahoochee Hills has no responsibility to build, improve, maintain, or otherwise service the Private Thoroughfares, drainage Improvements, and other appurtenances contained within the general public purpose Access and Utility Easement or Easements for Private Thoroughfares shown on this Plat. 
(2)  Grant of easement. The general purpose public access and utility easement shown on this plat for private thoroughfare is hereby granted and said grant of rights shall be liberally construed to provide all necessary authority to the city, and to public or private utility companies serving the subdivision, for the installation and maintenance of utilities, including, but not limited to, electric lines, gas lines, telephone lines, water lines, sewer lines, cable television lines, and fiber optic cables, together with the right to trim interfering trees and brush, together with a perpetual right of ingress and egress for installation, maintenance, and replacement of such lines.

Signature of Property Owner

Certificate of Dedication. All water and Sewer lines installed within the general purpose public Access and Utility Easement(s) shown on this Plat for Private Thoroughfare(s) are hereby dedicated to the City of Chattahoochee Hills or its assignee.

(h)  Requirement for purchaser's acknowledgement of private responsibilities. Prior to the sale or as a condition of the closing of a real estate transaction involving any lot served by a private thoroughfare in the city, the subdivider or seller of said lot shall execute a notarized purchaser's acknowledgement of private thoroughfare construction and drainage maintenance responsibilities as set forth below. A copy of the purchaser's acknowledgement shall be retained by the purchaser and shall be required to be submitted as a condition of a building permit for a principal building on said lot:

(Ord. No. 15-05-138, § 7.11, 5-5-2015) 
Sec. 26-120. - Dedications of thoroughfares and public lands. 
(a)  No thoroughfare or public land shall be dedicated to the city without prior approval by a vote of the city council. 
(b)  Upon completion of public improvement construction, the subdivider or land developer shall notify the director and request an inspection. The director shall inspect all public improvements and shall notify the subdivider or land developer by mail of nonacceptance or preliminary acceptance. If the public improvements are not acceptable, the reason for non-acceptance shall be stated and corrective measures shall be outlined in a letter of notification. Upon notification, the subdivider or land developer shall correct all deficiencies identified in the non-acceptance letter within the time limit established by the director. Once deficiencies are corrected, the subdivider or land developer shall again request inspection in writing. Acceptance of public improvements required by this chapter to be approved by the city council shall be forwarded to the city council by the director following approval. 
(c)  Subdivision thoroughfares and rights-of-way and other lands to be dedicated to the public shall be accepted and dedicated by the city only upon the delivery to the city council of the general warranty deed conveying fee simple title of such rights-of-way and lands. The warranty deed shall be accompanied by an attorney's certificate of title and a tax transfer form addressed to the city council certifying that the grantor in such deed is vested with marketable fee simple title to the property conveyed thereby, free and clear of all liens and encumbrances, and further, that the individual executing such deed has full authority to do so. Acceptance of such dedication shall be accomplished by resolution of the city council. 
(d)  All slope, drainage and utility easements, as well as necessary thoroughfare rights-of-way (as determined by the director) shall be provided by the subdivider at no cost to the city. 
(Ord. No. 15-05-138, § 7.12, 5-5-2015) 
Secs. 26-121—26-138. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - ENERGY AND SUSTAINABILITY 

Sec. 26-139. - Drainage and stormwater management. 
(a)  Light imprint stormwater management methods shall be used. Stormwater management methods employed shall be appropriate for the development intensity of the neighborhood. See Table 26-139. 
(b)  General requirements. An adequate drainage system, separate and independent of any sanitary sewer system and including any necessary ditches, pipes, culverts, intersectional drains, drop inlets, bridges, etc., shall be provided for the proper drainage of all surface water for all subdivisions and land developments. Sizing and location of all drainage structures shall be the responsibility of a registered professional engineer or land surveyor. Stormwater should be detained on site when possible. The city may require the use of on-site control methods such as retention or detention to mitigate the stormwater and drainage impacts of the proposed subdivisions and land developments. The planning commission shall not approve any preliminary plat of subdivision that does not make adequate provision for stormwater and floodwater runoff channels or basins as determined by the director. No building permit shall be issued for any building within a subdivision or development permit issued for the development of land, if there is not present throughout the subdivision or to the land development an adequate system of drainage and stormwater management. 
(c)  Method of design and capacity. Storm sewers, where required, shall be designed by the rational method, or other methods as approved by the city, and a copy of design computations shall be submitted along with required plans. Drainage improvements shall accommodate potential runoff from the entire upstream drainage area within the site and shall be designed to prevent increases in downstream flooding. Capacity for a ten-year storm or rain shall be provided for all thoroughfare drainage structures such as catch basin, inlets cross-drains, etc. Capacity for a 100-year frequency storm event shall be provided for all main drainage structures such as retention basins, principal storm sewers, and all types of flood protection works. 
(d)  District-wide site design that incorporates stormwater detention, retention, and infiltration in the common areas or open space is preferred. Shallow stormwater features that are designed to appear natural and that serve alternate uses in dry periods can be site amenities and should be incorporated when possible. 
Table 26-139. Light Imprint Stormwater Matrix 
LIGHT IMPRINT STORM DRAINAGE MATRIX 

(e)  Location of drainage facilities. Drainage facilities shall be located in the thoroughfare right-of-way or access easement where feasible, and shall be constructed in accordance with standards and specifications of the city. Catch basins shall be located at low points of thoroughfares. Where topography or other conditions are such as to make impractical the inclusion of drainage facilities within thoroughfare rights-of-way, perpetual, unobstructed easements at least 15 feet in width for drainage facilities shall be provided across property outside the thoroughfare right-of-way and with satisfactory access to the thoroughfare. 
(f)  Discharge. Drainage shall be designed so as to avoid concentration of storm drainage water from each lot or land development site to adjacent lots, land development sites, or vacant properties. Stormwater shall not be discharged directly to perennial streams. It shall be directed toward natural drainages. If water must be discharged to a stream, the water quality flowing into the stream must meet or exceed the water quality in the receiving waters. The water quantity flowing into the stream must be evaluated to ensure the stream channel can accommodate the increased flows and not disrupt or degrade the ecology of the water body. 
(g)  Grading and site drainage. Lots or land development sites shall be laid out so as to provide positive drainage away from all buildings, and drainage for individual lots or land development sites shall be coordinated with the general storm drainage pattern for the area. Buildings and parking lots shall be appropriately drained so as to prevent damage to abutting properties or public thoroughfares. All disturbed or graded ground areas of a building site not used for buildings or open storage areas shall be appropriately stabilized and grassed or covered with plants or landscaping materials. 
(h)  Cross-drainpipes. Where a watercourse separates the buildable area of a lot from the thoroughfare by which it has access, provisions shall be made for installation of a culvert or other structure, the design of which shall be approved by the city. Cross-drains shall be provided to accommodate all natural waterflow, and shall be of sufficient length to permit full-width thoroughfare and the required slopes. Cross-drainpipes shall have head walls of an approved type on inlet and outlet ends of the pipe. Pipe installed within the right-of-way shall be reinforced concrete pipe. All storm drainpipes shall be minimum 18 inches in diameter. Storm sewer slopes shall be equal to or greater than one percent. 
(i)  Drop inlets. Drop inlets shall be generally three-foot by three-foot boxes with two-foot by three-foot grates unless otherwise specified by the city. 
(j)  Easements. Where an irrigation ditch or channel, natural creek, stream or other drainage way crosses a subdivision or land development, the subdivider or developer shall provide an easement sufficient for drainage and maintenance. Easements shall be provided for all drainage facilities as approved by the city. When a subdivision or land development is traversed by a watercourse, drainage way, channel, or intermittent stream, a stormwater or drainage easement of at least 20 feet shall be provided. 
(k)  Grading and drainage plan. Preliminary plat applications shall submit a conceptual grading and drainage plan that demonstrates minimal disturbance and, to the extent consistent with applicable local, state, and federal law, stormwater management primarily through retention and percolation on site and adherence to light imprint stormwater design. 
(Ord. No. 15-05-138, § 8.1, 5-5-2015) 
Sec. 26-140. - Water. 
(a)  Generally. All habitable buildings and buildable lots shall be connected to a water supply capable of providing water for health and emergency purposes, including adequate fire protection. No permit shall be issued for any building within a subdivision or for the development of land, if there is not present throughout the subdivision or to the land development an adequate water supply, as determined by the city engineer. 
(b)  Water main requirements. When a public water main is accessible, the developer shall install adequate water facilities, including fire hydrants, according to specifications of the city. All water mains shall normally be at least six inches in diameter except that pipe of lesser size may be used if properly looped and adequate water pressure is maintained in accordance with standards established by the Southeastern Fire Underwriters Association. Pipe of less than four inches shall not be used except in unusual cases. Water lines shall be installed at least 30 inches below grade. Water mains within subdivisions and land developments must be provided with connections to each lot in the subdivision and each land development, except as otherwise specifically provided. 
(c)  Wells. If a county and/or municipal water supply is not available to the subdivision or land development at the time of constructing improvements for a subdivision or land development, then the subdivider or developer shall provide an adequate alternative water source and an adequate water storage facility. In subdivisions or land developments in an RL or HM-LDR district with a net residential density of two-thirds unit per acre or less and when a public water system is not available as determined by the city, individual wells may be used in a manner so that an adequate supply of potable water will be available to every lot in the subdivision or to the land development. When individual wells are proposed to be used for water supply, water samples shall be submitted to the county health department for its approval, and individual wells shall be approved by the county health department. Approvals shall be submitted to the director prior to final subdivision plat approval. 
(d)  Community water system. If a county and/or municipal water supply is not available to the subdivision or land development at the time of constructing improvements for a subdivision or land development, then the subdivider or developer shall provide an adequate alternative water source and an adequate water storage facility. Any community water system, if permitted, shall provide a minimum flow of 400 gallons per day per each lot platted, whether or not each lot is to be immediately developed; shall be sanitary; and shall have a minimum pressure of 45 pounds per square inch at each lot in the subdivision or each land development to be served. For all common non-public water supply systems, acceptable management, maintenance, and distribution policies and procedures shall be established. These policies and procedures shall be required to guarantee the provision of adequate supplies to each perspective lot owner on a continuing, ongoing basis, and to provide acceptable means for repairs and unforeseen events. The community water system plan shall be approved by the county health department and a letter of approval from the state department of natural resources shall accompany the final plat or land development application. 
(e)  Fire hydrants. Fire hydrants shall be required for all nonresidential land developments and all subdivisions except those permitted to be served by individual on-site wells or community wells that serve six or fewer homes. The agency having jurisdiction may permit sprinklered homes or businesses as an alternative when sufficient flow or pressure for hydrants is unavailable. Fire hydrants with appropriate water pressure at appropriate intervals throughout the subdivision or land development shall be provided by the subdivider or land developer as required by the city fire department. Fire hydrants shall be located no more than 500 feet apart and within 400 feet of any principal dwelling. Hydrants, fittings, valves and fire department connections shall be approved by the fire department. Fire department connections shall be not less than 18 inches or more than 36 inches above the level of the adjoining ground or paving. The thread of such connections shall be uniform with that used by the fire department. The agency having jurisdiction (AHJ) shall determine the sufficiency of hydrant type, placement, and hydrant pressure. To eliminate future thoroughfare openings, all underground utilities for fire hydrants, together with the fire hydrants themselves, and all other supply improvements shall be installed before any final paving of a thoroughfare within the right-of-way shared by such underground utilities. 
(Ord. No. 15-05-138, § 8.2, 5-5-2015) 
Sec. 26-141. - Sanitary sewer. 
(a)  Generally. All habitable buildings and buildable lots shall be served by an approved means of wastewater collection and treatment. Each subdivision and land development shall be served by adequate sewage disposal facilities. No permit shall be issued for any building within a subdivision or for the development of land, if there is not present throughout the subdivision or to the land development an adequate method of wastewater collection and treatment. Sewer systems are governed by the county and higher authorities. 
(b)  Connection to public sewerage system. When a public sanitary sewerage system is reasonably accessible, as determined by the city, the subdivider or land developer shall connect with it and provide sewers accessible to each lot in the subdivision or to each land development. 
(c)  Cluster systems. A cluster system is an individual subsurface sewage disposal system, which in whole or component part serves more than one property, dwelling, commercial unit or other realty improvement. Cluster systems shall be governed by the following provisions: 
(1)  Cluster systems shall be licensed by the state department of natural resources environmental protection division (EPD) or the county department of environmental health and shall satisfactorily comply with all terms of the license. 
(2)  The system shall be licensed and fully operational before final plat approval. No lot served by the system shall be sold nor shall any building permit be issued before the cluster system is approved for operation. 
(3)  The disposal field shall not be located on any 100 year floodplain or within 200 feet of any groundwater recharge area. 
(4)  Ownership, maintenance and operation of a cluster system. 
a.  Upon transfer of title by the developer, a homeowners' association comprised of the owners of each lot serviced by the system, or a separate authority, shall own, maintain, operate, repair and replace, system components located outside of individual property lot lines. In the event the homeowners' association includes owners whose properties are not serviced by the system, those owners shall not be responsible for maintenance, operation, repairs and replacement of the system. The homeowners' association shall not be dissolved and may not dispose of the system, by sale or otherwise, without the prior approval of the city. 
b.  The by-laws, membership assessments and dues, and methods of enforcement and collection of delinquent assessments and dues of the homeowners' association insofar as they pertain to maintenance, operation, repair and replacement of the cluster system shall be submitted to and approved by the city prior to or as a condition of final plat approval. 
c.  A separate capital account dedicated to replacement of the system based upon the useful life of its component parts and funded through association assessments shall be established and approved by the city prior to final plat approval. The owner of the system shall provide to the city a bond, escrow, or equivalent security valued at the difference between the cost of replacing the system and balance of the capital account. 
d.  Declaration of covenants, conditions, restrictions and by-laws shall be recorded with the Fulton County clerk of superior court in the book for the recording of deeds, which recording shall be prior to final plat approval or the first conveyance of any realty improvements to be serviced by a cluster system. 
e.  The city shall not be responsible for any dry sewer lines installed as part of major subdivision approval and used for the transfer or pumping of sewage to any cluster system. During the period of such use, the legal entity responsible for maintenance, operation, repair and replacement of the system shall remain fully responsible for the system. 
f.  Prior to final plat approval, the owner of a cluster system shall place with the city an escrow, performance bond, or other security approved by the city for two years of operating costs. In the event the owner fails to operate the system within the terms of the EPD license, the city may assume control of the system and draw upon this security. The city may also assume all billing for sewer service and spend all money collected to manage, operate, maintain, or repair the system. 
g.  Prior to final plat approval, the owner of a cluster system shall submit to the city a manual explaining in detail the operation and maintenance of the system. Such a manual shall be kept at all times by the owner and shall be updated as necessary. Copies of any and all updates shall be provided to the city. 
h.  The owner of a cluster system approved by the city shall, as a continuing condition of approval, engage and maintain the services of a sewage treatment plant operator, licensed in the state, to provide the necessary expertise for the maintenance, operation, repair and replacement of the system. The city shall receive at least 60 days' notice of the cancellation, termination, expiration or non-renewal of the licensed operator's contract with the owner. These requirements may be waived by the city, upon a showing of good cause by the owner. The licensed operator shall be subject to the requirement of this chapter pertaining to maintenance, inspections, reporting and operation. 
i.  All costs of any testing or monitoring of a cluster system or its components shall be borne by the applicant or association, as the case may be. 
(5)  Access to cluster systems. 
a.  As a condition to approval of a cluster system, the applicant shall provide to the city all necessary easements (by deed) granting the city and its authorized agent access to all properties upon which the system is located and/or which the system services for the purpose of monitoring and inspecting the system and, where necessary, disconnecting a component of the system in order to protect the integrity of the system as a whole. This provision shall not be construed to be in derogation of any authority to enter premises the city and its authorized agent may otherwise have by reason of statute, rule or ordinance. 
b.  As a condition to approval of a cluster system, the applicant shall provide to the owner of the system, and its successors, assigns and agents, all necessary easements (by deed) granting the owner access to all properties upon which the system is located and/or which the system services for the purpose of monitoring, inspecting, and pumping and cleaning the system in order to protect the integrity of the system as a whole. 
(d)  Septic tanks. Where individual on-site wastewater disposal systems are allowed and proposed, individual lot sizes and shapes must exhibit appropriate regard for the peculiar health, drainage, and maintenance characteristics on the site. Additionally, detailed soil tests may be required in order to verify the ability of the lots to safely contain and dispose of septic system effluent. All septic tanks and on-site wastewater disposal systems are subject to the approval of the county health department. The minimum lot size for a septic system is one acre (43,560 square feet). No building permit shall be issued for a lot with a septic system, or a proposed septic system, without the approval of the county department of environmental health. No certificate of occupancy shall be issued without a final inspection by and approval of the county department of environmental health, and receipt of as-built drawings of the septic system. 
(Ord. No. 15-05-138, § 8.3, 5-5-2015) 
Sec. 26-142. - Utilities. 
(a)  In all HM, VL, and TN districts, all utility facilities, including but not limited to gas, electric power, telephone, and cable television, shall be located underground throughout the subdivision or land development. 
(b)  Whenever existing utility facilities in HM, VL, and TN districts (other than major transmission lines) are located above ground, except when existing with public thoroughfares rights-of-way, they shall be removed and placed underground. Transmission lines should also be relocated underground. Easements centered on rear lot lines shall be provided for utilities, private and public, and such easements shall be at least ten feet wide. 
(c)  When topographical or other conditions are such as to make impractical the inclusion of utilities along the rear lot lines of a subdivision, lot, or land development site, perpetual unobstructed easements at least ten feet in width shall be provided alongside lot lines with satisfactory access. 
(d)  Utility thoroughfare crossings indicated on the plat or construction plans to be buried shall be installed before the thoroughfare is paved. 
(Ord. No. 15-05-138, § 8.4, 5-5-2015) 
Sec. 26-143. - Oversizing of improvements and utilities. 
(a)  The subdivider or land developer shall construct such oversized improvements and utilities that the city determines are necessary, provided that the subdivider or land developer shall not be obligated for the additional cost of improvements and utilities that are not uniquely required for that development, and provided the subdivider agrees to a proposal by the city to share in the cost arrangements for over-sizing improvements and utilities. 
(b)  A formula may be developed by the city to provide for a sharing of the cost of other improvements needed to serve the subdivision or land development when certain of the improvements are necessary to serve future subdivisions or developments in the vicinity. 
(Ord. No. 15-05-138, § 8.5, 5-5-2015) 
Secs. 26-144—26-169. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - OPEN SPACE 

Sec. 26-170. - Purpose. 
(a)  It is the purpose and intent of this article to: 
(1)  Ensure preservation of open space within developments; 
(2)  Provide flexibility to allow for creativity in developments; 
(3)  Minimize the environmental and visual impacts of new development on critical natural resources and historically and culturally significant sites and structures; 
(4)  Provide an interconnected network of permanent open space; 
(5)  Encourage a more efficient form of development that consumes less open land and conforms to existing topography and natural features; 
(6)  Reduce erosion and sedimentation by minimizing land disturbance and removal of vegetation; 
(7)  Enhance the community character; 
(8)  Permit clustering of houses and structures which will reduce the amount of infrastructure, including paved surfaces and utility lines; 
(9)  Encourage thoroughfare design that controls traffic speeds and creates thoroughfare inter-connectivity; and 
(10)  Promote construction of convenient and accessible walking trails and bike paths both within a subdivision and connected to neighboring communities, businesses and facilities to reduce reliance on automobiles. 
(b)  Open space for all developments shall be as regulated in chapter 35, zoning. 
(c)  Activities within the open space are restricted in perpetuity through the use of a conservation easement. The open space shall be designated on the preliminary plat and recorded on the final plat. 
(Ord. No. 15-05-138, § 9.1, 5-5-2015) 
Sec. 26-171. - Open space networks configuration. 
(a)  Properties designated as open space shall be configured to create or maintain a network of open space. 
(b)  No more than five percent of the preservation area shall be fewer than 50 feet in width. 
(c)  No open space shall share a lot with any use not listed on Table 35-265. Any such unlisted use shall be separated from the open space by a parcel boundary and a thoroughfare or permanent fence line. 
(d)  All open space networks shall provide connectivity to any common areas within the development and to any adjacent public places, paths or rights-of-way. 
(e)  Paths located in floodplains, stream buffers, or within 25 feet of wetlands shall be constructed of pervious materials. 
(f)  Where path networks cross internal subdivision thoroughfares or public thoroughfares, access points shall be directly across from each other. 
(g)  Crossings and access points shall be clearly identified to pedestrians and motorists and may include traffic control devices, bridges and tunnels. 
(h)  Open space preservation areas, as defined in chapter 35, zoning, shall include the following features when they are present on the site: 
(1)  Habitats for endangered or threatened species as defined by the state department of natural resources; 
(2)  Wetlands identified by the National Wetlands Inventory maps prepared by the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, the county soil survey prepared by the United States Department of Agriculture (USDA) Natural Resources Conservation Service, or a certified wetlands delineation using data from the U. S. Army Corps of Engineers; 
(3)  Alluvial soils identified by the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) and 100-year floodplain; 
(4)  Rivers, streams, lakes, existing ponds, naturalistic stormwater management ponds/facilities with pedestrian amenities, creeks, including, but not limited to, blue line tributaries and state waters; 
(5)  Riparian zones equal to any required stream buffers and improvement setbacks; 
(6)  Existing slopes greater than 25 percent on average with a site area greater than 5,000 square feet identified as part of a site analysis conducted by a registered engineer, land surveyor or landscape architect; and 
(7)  Historic and/or archaeological sites. 
(Ord. No. 15-05-138, § 9.2, 5-5-2015; Ord. No. 16-03-149, § 1, 3-1-2016) 
Sec. 26-172. - Open space protection and maintenance. 
(a)  Open space areas required by city ordinance shall be protected in perpetuity from further development or unauthorized use by a conservation easement. The city reserves the right to enforce all such required conservation easements. 
(b)  Such conservation easements shall: 
(1)  Clearly delineate conservation areas; 
(2)  Describe the features of the subject property that shall be permanently protected in accordance with the Georgia Uniform Conservation Easement Act, O.C.G.A. § 44-10-1 et seq.; 
(3)  List the parties, that is, the owners of the property, the holder of the easement and the city as a third party beneficiary with rights to enforce the easement if the city is not the holder; 
(4)  Specify how the easement may be transferred as in the case of the dissolution of a homeowners association; 
(5)  Clearly identify the boundaries of the property by survey and a metes and bounds legal description;
