(3)  Layout. Preservation areas shall be designated as rural areas and shall be designed as set forth in chapter 26. 
(b)  Preservation areas may include land utilized for meeting buffer requirements. However, when buffer areas alone do not fully satisfy the preservation area requirement then additional preservation area shall still be provided. 
Table 35-265. Open Space 

 
;hn0; (Ord. No. 15-05-137, § 2.3(B), 5-5-2015) 
Sec. 35-266. - Civic areas. 
(a)  Civic areas shall be provided in accordance with the provisions of the following subsections: 
(1)  Amount. The minimum amount of required civic areas is five percent of the minimum required open space as set forth for each individual zoning district in Table 35-461. 
(2)  Uses. 
a.  The permitted uses allowed in civic areas shall be as set forth in Table 35-265. 
b.  The director may approve the allocation of other civic uses in lieu of those listed when such uses are agreed to be operated or managed by the city or through an MOU with the city for the following uses: city hall, fire stations, police stations, libraries, museums or nature centers. 
c.  The listed civic uses of subsection (a)(2)b of this section shall be limited to a maximum total area of 25 percent of all civic areas provided within an individual zoning district. 
(3)  Layout. Civic areas shall be designated as rural or non-rural and shall be designed as set forth in Table 35-266. 
(4)  Location. Civic areas shall be located within 800 feet of property with any use other than agricultural uses as delineated in Table 35-595. Such individual civic areas shall be a minimum size of either the smallest parcel located within 800 feet of the civic area or 5,000 square feet, whichever is less. 
(b)  Civic areas shall be designed so as to: 
(1)  Provide active or passive recreational amenities; 
(2)  Be visible and accessible from the adjacent sidewalk; and 
(3)  Permit and encourage pedestrians to walk on a minimum of 80 percent of the surface of the area excluding fountains, pedestrian furniture, public art and similar elements. 
Table 35-266. Civic Areas 

(Ord. No. 15-05-137, § 2.3(C), 5-5-2015) 
Sec. 35-267. - Demarcation. 
(a)  Lots adjacent to open space shall demarcate the location of the property line adjacent to such open space through the installation of permanent in-ground markers at each adjacent corner of the lot. The design of the in-ground markers shall be approved by the city. 
(b)  Demarcations may alternatively utilize those approved features which achieve permanent visual differentiation between properties to the greatest possible degree. 
(c)  Thoroughfares utilized for purposes of satisfying this requirement shall be continuously connected to at least one other off-site thoroughfare. 
(d)  Any improvements used to satisfy these demarcation requirements shall be continually maintained. 
(Ord. No. 15-05-137, § 2.3(D), 5-5-2015) 
Sec. 35-268. - Landscaping. 
Landscaped areas with grass, trees, shrubs, hedges and/or other landscaping materials shall be approved by the city arborist. 
(Ord. No. 15-05-137, § 2.3(E), 5-5-2015) 
Sec. 35-269. - Maintenance. 
(a)  Proposed open spaces included in approved zoning plans shall also include information delineating the entity responsible for the ownership, maintenance, and for resolution of issues related to such areas. 
(b)  The entity designated by subsection (a) of this section shall provide adequate maintenance of the open space improvements and shall replace dead plantings when necessary. See the subdivision and land development ordinance for additional regulations related to open space maintenance. 
(Ord. No. 15-05-137, § 2.3(F), 5-5-2015) 
Sec. 35-270. - Above ground stormwater ponds. 
Stormwater ponds functioning as management facilities designed to control stormwater runoff from multiple buildings or properties may be permitted to be counted towards required open space provided such facilities contain pedestrian amenities connecting the facility to adjacent uses. 
(Ord. No. 15-05-137, § 2.3(G), 5-5-2015) 
Sec. 35-271. - Transfer of open space requirements. 
Open space requirements may be transferred to an offsite parcel when meeting the following requirements. 
(1)  The city council finds that the transferred open space provides demonstrably greater value to the community than if the open space were not transferred off site. The council will consider the following in making its determination: 
a.  Whether the off-site preservation protects 120 percent of the acreage otherwise required if not transferred. 
b.  Whether the off-site preservation protects a site currently identified as a "scenic area" in the city's TDR program. 
c.  Whether the off-site preservation connects elements of the city's greenspace network. 
d.  Whether the off-site preservation provides public Chattahoochee River access. 
e.  Whether the off-site preservation protects and/or provides public access to some valued landscape, viewscape, historic site, cultural feature or other valued amenity unique to its site. 
(2)  The following transfer methods may be utilized: 
a.  The purchase of property and subsequent application of a conservation easement to that property in accordance with the open space protection standards in chapter 26; 
b.  The purchase of development rights via the transferable development rights (TDR) program (see chapter 14, article II), where one TDR shall equal one acre of transferred open space requirement; or 
c.  A payment in lieu of direct preservation as regulated under density transfer charges in chapter 14, article II. 
(3)  In no case shall the transfer of open space requirements result in development that does not comply with the remaining regulations of this district. 
(4)  Open space requirements may only be transferred to parcels located within the RL district. 
(5)  Required civic areas shall be required to remain on-site and shall be prohibited from such a transfer. 
(6)  The off-site parcel receiving the open space requirements ("receiving parcel") shall contain the amount of open space otherwise required for any permitted development on said receiving parcel in addition to the transferred amount of open space. 
(7)  Open space requirements fulfilled on a receiving parcel shall be documented on approved zoning and development plans. Such documentation shall include the total amount of open space relocated and the location of the receiving parcel. 
(8)  Once transferred to a receiving parcel, the square footage of such transferred open space shall not be used or credited toward future open space transfers. 
(9)  The maximum amount of the open space requirement that can be transferred off-site as a percentage of the total open space area is as listed below: 
a.  RL district: off-site transfer is prohibited. 
b.  HM districts: ten percent. 
c.  VL district: ten percent. 
d.  TN district: ten percent. 
(10)  Open space requirements transferred to an offsite parcel shall be counted toward the district minimum acreage requirements set forth in Table 35-461. 
(Ord. No. 15-05-137, § 2.3(H), 5-5-2015) 
Sec. 35-272. - Buffers. 
(a)  Buffer areas to be provided. Buffer areas shall be provided in accordance with the provisions of the following subsections: 
(1)  Amount. The minimum amount of required buffer areas shall be as set forth in Table 35-272. In case of conflicting buffer dimension requirements, the largest buffer requirement shall be considered the effective buffer dimension requirement. 
(2)  Uses. The permitted uses allowed in buffer areas shall be as set forth for preservation areas in Table 35-265. Such uses in the buffer areas do not reduce the visual buffering required. 
(3)  Landscaping. Any barren or disturbed portion of the buffer area is to be planted/replanted with a mix of deciduous and evergreen trees at an appropriate replacement size, where soil conditions permit, as approved by the director. 
(4)  Rural character exceptions. 
a.  In the RL district, existing agricultural uses, stand-alone single-family residential uses, and residential minor subdivision lots that are not a part of a farmette development shall not be subject to buffer requirements. 
b.  Any properties within an HM, VL, or TN district that are outside of the district buffer shall be regulated by the RL district standards. 
(b)  Measurements. 
(1)  Zoning district buffers. Buffer dimensions for zoning district boundaries shall be measured as a linear depth from the edge of the designated property boundary or zoning district boundary, or the boundary of any property to which the rural character exception defined subsection (a)(4)b of this section, applies. When such boundary includes a thoroughfare, the dimension shall be measured from the interior edge of the right-of-way of said thoroughfare. 
(2)  Thoroughfare buffers. Buffer dimensions for thoroughfares shall be measured as a linear depth from the edges of the right-of-way. 
(3)  Buildings shall have an additional ten-foot setback interior to buffers. 
(4)  Buffer areas shall have a minimum amount of undisturbed area equal to a minimum of 50 percent of the total required buffer area. Such undisturbed areas shall be planted with evergreen plant material and deciduous trees limited to native species, as permitted by the director. Areas with existing tree coverage may utilize such areas for meeting this calculation. 
(c)  Building visibility. 
(1)  Buildings and structures shall be located so as to limit visibility to the greatest degree possible from outside of the respective individual zoning district into the district and its prospective development. 
(2)  Where such visibility is unavoidable, additional design features shall be incorporated to minimize visibility including the utilization of exterior earth tone colors, natural materials and architectural features. 
(3)  When landscaping is not sufficient to provide a full visual buffer, the director may require additional screening devices for purposes of providing adequate buffering. Such screening devices may include solid decorative brick walls, wood fences, natural berms, or evergreen hedges, or a combination of said devices. The director may also reduce buffer width requirements when topography provides visual buffering at lesser distances than required. 
Table 35-272. Buffer Standards 

 
;hn0; (Ord. No. 15-05-137, § 2.3(I), 5-5-2015) 
Secs. 35-273—35-292. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - DISTRICTS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 35-293. - Establishment of zoning districts. 
For the purposes of this zoning ordinance, the city is divided into zoning districts that provide opportunities for residents of the city to conduct business and to interact with nature, with agriculture and with others. The zoning districts of the city are designated as follows: 
(Ord. No. 15-05-137, § 3.1, 5-5-2015) 
Sec. 35-294. - RL, Rural District. 
The RL, Rural District is intended primarily for lower density agricultural and single-family residential uses with individual lot sewage systems. This district is designed to stabilize and protect the rural and residential characteristics of the city and to encourage single-family uses on larger lots. 
(Ord. No. 15-05-137, § 3.1(A), 5-5-2015) 
Sec. 35-295. - HM, Hamlet District. 
The HM, Hamlet District is intended primarily for the creation of larger mixed use communities developed at a low overall density. This district provides a location for agricultural and residential uses to live in close proximity to smaller scaled commercial, office, manufacturing or civic uses complete with design standards and parameters to encourage a pedestrian-friendly traditional urban form which enhances community aesthetics and limits conflicts between vehicles and pedestrians. The Hamlet District consists of four subdistricts: 
(1)  HM-LDR, Hamlet Low-Density Residential District. This HM subdistrict is intended primarily for lower density residential areas. This subdistrict allows agricultural or residential uses to be provided at higher densities than in the RL district. 
(2)  HM-MDR, Hamlet Medium-Density Residential District. This HM subdistrict is intended primarily for medium-density residential areas with community sewage. This subdistrict allows predominantly residential development with additional minor mixed uses. 
(3)  HM-SD, Hamlet Special District. This HM subdistrict is intended for smaller hamlet districts that are focused on a specific use or type of uses consistent with the city's comprehensive plan but not otherwise covered in this article. 
(4)  HM-MU, Hamlet Mixed Use District. This HM subdistrict is intended primarily for medium-density residential areas and mixed use areas. 
(Ord. No. 15-05-137, § 3.1(B), 5-5-2015) 
Sec. 35-296. - VL, Village District. 
The VL, Village District is intended primarily for the creation of larger mixed use communities developed at a medium-density. This district allows agricultural and residential uses to live in close proximity to medium scale commercial, office, manufacturing or civic uses complete with design standards and parameters to reduce the dependence on automobiles, to encourage fine-scale mixed uses, a pedestrian-friendly traditional urban form which enhances community aesthetics and limits conflicts between vehicles and pedestrians. No part of any VL district shall be within five miles of a TN district or another VL district, as measured in a straight line. 
(Ord. No. 15-05-137, § 3.1(C), 5-5-2015) 
Sec. 35-297. - TN, Town District. 
The TN, Town District is intended primarily for the creation of larger mixed use communities developed at a high density. This district provides a location for agricultural and residential uses to live in close proximity to larger scaled commercial, office, manufacturing or civic uses complete with design standards and parameters to reduce the dependence on automobiles, to encourage fine-scale mixed uses, a pedestrian-friendly traditional urban form which enhances community aesthetics and limits conflicts between vehicles and pedestrians. No part of any TN district shall be within ten miles of another TN district or within five miles of a VL district, as measured in a straight line. 
(Ord. No. 15-05-137, § 3.1(D), 5-5-2015) 
Sec. 35-298. - PC, Parkway Commercial District. 
The PC, Parkway Commercial District provides opportunities for fully buffered, small scale commercial uses in limited locations along South Fulton Parkway. 
(Ord. No. 15-05-137, § 3.1(E), 5-5-2015) 
Sec. 35-299 - HC, Historic Crossroads District. 
The HC, Historic Crossroads District is intended to reactivate settlements that used to exist at several crossroads identified in the comprehensive plan. This district provides locations for small scale commercial uses and residential uses at higher densities appropriate for a small town center, in a context of historic character. Development in the district is subject to design and architectural standards that are the most specific and strict in the city, along with parameters to encourage a pedestrian-friendly traditional urban form which enhances community aesthetics and limits conflicts between vehicles and pedestrians. 
( Ord. No. 18-07-182 , § 1, 7-3-2018) 
Secs. 35-300—35-329. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - MINIMUM STANDARDS 

Sec. 35-330. - Uniform application. 
The regulations set forth in this chapter within each district shall be minimum regulations and shall apply uniformly to each class or kind of structure or land, except as otherwise provided. 
(Ord. No. 15-05-137, § 3.2(A), 5-5-2015) 
Sec. 35-331. - ADA compliance. 
In addition to the regulations of this chapter, the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) accessibility guidelines for buildings and facilities shall also apply, as amended. 
(Ord. No. 15-05-137, § 3.2(B), 5-5-2015) 
Sec. 35-332. - Applicability to land, buildings and open space. 
No building, structure, land, or open space shall hereafter be used or occupied and no building or structure or part thereof shall hereafter be erected, demolished, constructed, reconstructed, moved, or structurally altered unless in conformity with all of the regulations herein specified for the district in which it is located. 
(Ord. No. 15-05-137, § 3.2(C), 5-5-2015) 
Sec. 35-333. - Measurement of distance. 
All distance measurements of this chapter that do not specify the method of measurement shall be measured in a straight line from the nearest property line to the nearest property line. 
(Ord. No. 15-05-137, § 3.2(D), 5-5-2015) 
Sec. 35-334. - License requirements. 
All uses requiring an occupation tax and business license, or other type of license, shall comply with all such licensing requirements and shall not be considered lawful uses under this chapter if in violation of such licensing requirements. 
(Ord. No. 15-05-137, § 3.2(E), 5-5-2015) 
Secs. 35-335—35-356. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - SITE DEVELOPMENT REQUIREMENTS 

Sec. 35-357. - Lots and frontages. 
(a)  Lot. 
(1)  A group of two or more contiguous lots owned by the same entity and used for a single use shall be considered a single lot. 
(2)  The term "lot" shall not include any portion of a dedicated right-of-way. 
(3)  Lots shall be further regulated by chapter 26. 
(b)  Lot frontage. 
(1)  A property line adjoining a stub thoroughfare shall not be considered as frontage unless it is proposed for access or is the only thoroughfare frontage. 
(2)  In situations where a multiple frontage lot has equal distance on thoroughfare frontages, the director shall determine the legal lot frontage. 
(c)  Lot line, rear. For a pointed or irregular lot, the rear lot line shall be an imaginary line, parallel to and the most distant from the front lot line, not less than 20 feet long, and wholly within the lot. 
(1)  True triangular lots do not have rear lot lines. Lots with more than one front lot line do not have rear lot lines. 
(2)  The director shall make the final determination of rear lot lines when in dispute or undefined by this definition. 
(d)  Layers. Lots are divided into first, second and third layers according to their position on the lot which control development as established in Table 35-357. 
Table 35-357. Layers 

(e)  Thoroughfare frontage requirements. 
(1)  Every building hereafter erected or moved shall be on a lot adjacent to a thoroughfare or open space and all structures shall be so located on lots as to provide safe and convenient access for servicing, fire protection, and required off-street parking. 
(2)  Lots facing thoroughfares or open spaces on more than one side shall have designated primary frontages and may have secondary frontages. A primary frontage when facing a thoroughfare, shall be that frontage facing the thoroughfare of higher intensity including traffic volume, number of lanes, pedestrian activity, as determined by the director. 
(f)  Lot reduction prohibited. No lot, even though it may consist of one or more adjacent lots of record, shall be reduced in size so that the lot width or depth, front, side or rear yards, lot area per dwelling unit or other requirements of this chapter are not maintained. Yards or lots created after the effective date of the ordinance from which this chapter is derived shall meet at least the minimum requirements established by this chapter. This section shall not apply when a portion of a lot is acquired for a public purpose. 
(g)  Lots not meeting minimum lot size requirements. When a lot has an area or frontage which does not conform to the requirements of the district in which it is located, but was a lot of record at the effective date of the ordinance from which this chapter is derived or upon amendments thereto, such lot may be used for any use allowed in the zoning district in which it is located provided that all other requirements of this chapter are met. 
(h)  Lots with wells and septic tanks. Any lot upon which both an individual well and septic tank/drain field are utilized shall be governed by regulations of the county health department. Lots utilizing both a well and a septic tank shall be not less than one acre in size. Any lot proposed to be served by either a well or a septic tank/drain field shall comply with the larger of the minimum lot area required by the county health code or the minimum required for the district in which the lot is located. 
(i)  Limitations on minor subdivisions. Minor subdivisions in HM, VL and TN zoning districts shall be prohibited. 
(j)  Yards. In addition to uses which may be provided for, conditioned or excluded from yards by other sections of this chapter, yards may be used for driveways, signs, parking, loading areas, fountains, flagpoles, yard ornaments, walls, fences, walkways, lawns, buffers, landscape areas, underground utilities, well houses, stormwater management facilities and tree preservation areas. No part of any yard or use made thereof shall serve the requirements for any other lot or structure. 
(Ord. No. 15-05-137, § 3.3.1, 5-5-2015) 
Sec. 35-358. - Site improvements and standards. 
(a)  These standards shall regulate site improvement, and the provision of amenities related to site improvement. Below are the minimum standards for all districts. 
(1)  Minimum setback for new public and private streets. The right-of-way for new public streets and the easement or common area for new private streets shall be located a minimum of 50 feet from any peripheral property line unless interparcel access is required. 
(2)  Dams. All dams within the jurisdiction of the city shall comply with the provisions of the Safe Dam Act and rules of the state department of natural resources. 
(3)  Building setback from pipeline easement. 
a.  Setback requirements. No buildings used for human occupancy shall be permitted within 40 feet of any easement containing a gathering or transmission line. 
b.  Land use restrictions. No building or structure or part thereof, which is used for the manufacturing, processing, generation or storage of any material in the following list shall be constructed within 125 feet of any gathering or transmission line easement: 
1.  Corrosive materials. 
2.  Highly toxic materials. 
3.  Oxidizing materials. 
4.  Pyrophoric materials. 
5.  Water reactive materials. 
6.  Highly combustible materials. 
7.  Flammable materials. 
8.  Explosive materials. 
9.  Materials that pose a hazard to human health. 
10.  Loose or combustible materials. 
(4)  Exceptions and exemptions. This subsection shall not apply to: 
a.  Any land disturbance or construction necessary to provide access to a property, when no other reasonable access is permitted, or any building, land disturbance or construction necessary to provide utility service to a parcel of land; 
b.  Any land disturbance or construction on a gathering or transmission line by or on behalf of the owner or operator of the gathering or transmission line; 
c.  Any driveway, street, parking lot, tennis court, volleyball court, play area, recreational area, deck, patio, or any other impervious surfaces. 
(5)  Variance criteria. The reconstruction of any structure existing at the time of adoption of the ordinance from which this chapter is derived that does not comply with the terms of this subsection (a) may apply for reconstruction on same foot print when safety permits. Any other deviation to the requirements of this section shall require a variance in accordance with section 35-116. 
(6)  Land disturbance permit requirements. In addition to any other requirements contained herein, all land disturbance permit applications shall provide the following: 
a.  A survey by a professional engineer or land surveyor licensed in the state indicating the location of all gathering or transmission line easements and rights-of-way indicating: 
b.  Gathering or transmission line plan location and depth; 
c.  Gathering or transmission line size; 
d.  The location of all off-site gathering or transmission line easements and rights-of-way within 40 feet of the boundaries of the subject property. 
(7)  Burying of construction material. No person shall bury unused, scrap, waste, excess or discarded construction material. Any person who violates this provision shall be deemed guilty of an ordinance violation and subject to the provisions of sections 35-37 and 35-38. 
(8)  Wastewater pump and lift stations. Wastewater pump and lift stations shall provide a minimum 50-foot buffer and ten-foot improvement setback along all property lines adjacent to residentially and/or agriculturally zoned properties used for residential or public recreational purposes. 
(b)  These standards shall regulate site improvement, and the provision of amenities related to site improvement. Below are additional minimum standards for HM, VL, and TN districts: 
(1)  Off-street parking. Property owners shall provide and maintain off-street parking throughout construction. Parking on any lot other than the lot for which a building permit is issued must be approved for a temporary parking lot by the director. 
(2)  Interparcel access. Interparcel access shall be provided to adjacent properties upon determination by the director that such access is in the best interest of the public health, safety or welfare. 
(3)  Sidewalks, curb and gutters. Sidewalks and curb and gutters shall be provided in accordance with city standards. 
(4)  Stormwater detention facilities. On-site stormwater detention facilities shall not be located within any required buffer or landscape strip. Detention facilities shall not be located within parking or loading areas unless approved by the department of public works. A 20-foot-wide landscape strip planted to buffer standards shall be provided around the exterior of the detention area outside of the access easement or as may be approved by the city arborist. 
(5)  Compliance with tree preservation ordinance. Prior to applying for a land disturbance permit, the owner shall arrange with the city arborist, through the director of the department of community development, for an on-site evaluation of existing specimen trees and stands of trees, and an evaluation of buffers and tree protection zones, and to ascertain compliance with the tree preservation ordinance found in chapter 14, article IX. At a minimum, the tree density requirements prescribed by the city tree preservation ordinance administrative guidelines shall be provided and permanently maintained. 
(6)  South Fulton Greenway Trail. At the time of application for a land disturbance permit or building permit, development projects with frontage adjacent to the roads identified on the South Fulton Greenway Trail master plan map shall incorporate a multi-use path subject to the approval of the director. Such path shall conform to the entry and exit points of the development project property as designated on the South Fulton Greenway Trail master plan map or as approved by the director, but the detail of the in-site alignment may be amended to suit the needs of the development, provided that in no case shall more than ten percent of the path alignment consist of thoroughfare sidewalks. Paths should be buffered by at least 100 feet of undisturbed buffer wherever practical. 
(Ord. No. 15-05-137, § 3.3.2, 5-5-2015) 
Sec. 35-359. - Buildings and building areas. 
(a)  Building setbacks. 
(1)  Primary facade setbacks shall be as established in Table 35-359. 
(2)  For buildings with more than one thoroughfare frontage, the sides of the building with frontage shall meet the public frontage and private frontage requirements for that district as specified in Tables 35-213-1, 35-213-2, and 35-213-3. 
Table 35-359. Street Type Dimensions 

 
(b)  Building setback encroachments. 
(1)  Cornices, eaves, steps, gutters, fire chases, chimneys, porches, bay windows, or other similar architectural features that are a part of an exterior wall of a structure, and fire escapes may extend into the required setbacks, provided such extensions do not exceed three feet. 
(2)  Steps and landings may extend into the required setbacks provided such extensions do not exceed ten feet for the primary facade setback, three feet for the side yard and are no closer than ten feet from the property line in the rear yard. 
(3)  Stairs, porches, canopies, fences, walls, outdoor dining areas, seating areas and vending areas shall be permitted within the first layer (Table 35-357), provided sufficient area is preserved within the sidewalk area for safe pedestrian circulation as approved by the director. 
(4)  Cantilevered portions of buildings, including decks and awnings, shall be permitted to extend over the sidewalk provided a minimum vertical ceiling height of 12 feet is maintained over the sidewalk. 
(5)  Encroachments of whole or partial portions of buildings or structures into any public right-of-way shall be prohibited. 
(6)  See Table 35-359 for provisions related to building setbacks. 
(c)  Building height and density. 
(1)  Building heights shall be as established in Table 35-359, except that building heights in HM, VL, and TN districts may be higher if the building is not visible from outside of the district, subject to the approval of the director, the fire department and the city's engineer. 
(2)  No building or other structure shall hereafter be erected or altered to exceed the height or bulk limits of this chapter; to accommodate or house a greater number of families; to occupy a greater percentage of lot area; to have narrower or smaller primary facade setbacks, rear yards, side yards, or other open spaces than herein required; or in any other manner contrary to the provisions of this chapter. 
(3)  Building height bonus. Buildings in HM, VL and TN districts shall be permitted an additional height bonus above the respective district maximum height limit in accordance with the following regulations: 
a.  Individual buildings providing senior housing for a minimum of 50 percent of the total building floor area shall be permitted an additional 30 feet of building height; 
b.  Individual buildings that visually terminate the viewshed of a public thoroughfare or open space through use of architectural detailing, massing and delineation shall be permitted an additional 20 feet of building height; and 
c.  Individual buildings within a VL or TN district containing a minimum of 100,000 square feet of any of the following uses shall be permitted an additional 20 feet of building height: communication; industrial and wholesale; transportation and warehousing; educational; places of worship; and public or governmental use. 
(4)  The height limitations of this chapter shall not apply to religious institution spires, belfries, cupolas, domes, transmission towers, chimneys, smokestacks, derricks, conveyors, flagpoles, silos and grain elevators, fire towers, masts, clock towers, cooling towers, water tanks, or mechanical bulkheads. However, such elements shall be prohibited from heights in excess of 199 feet above grade. 
(5)  Flat roofs shall be enclosed by parapets a minimum of four feet in height. 
(d)  Buildings in non-rural areas. 
(1)  Building orientation in non-rural areas. 
a.  All buildings shall be oriented to face the thoroughfare of greatest intensity or accessible external open space, as determined by the director. 
b.  Individual uses shall have pedestrian entrances directly adjacent to the sidewalk and oriented towards the thoroughfare of higher intensity including traffic volume, number of lanes, pedestrian activity as determined by the director. This requirement shall not be interpreted to prohibit secondary entrances on the sides of buildings. 
c.  Buildings also may be oriented to face a courtyard and individual uses may have pedestrian entrances that open directly to a courtyard 
d.  Residential garages shall be located so as to be directly accessible from the thoroughfare of lesser intensity including traffic volume, number of lanes, pedestrian activity as determined by the director. If oriented to the front of a house, residential garages may not project toward the street. 
e.  Decks and patios may extend to the side or rear yard property line. 
(2)  Fenestration in non-rural areas. 
a.  Display windows and pedestrian entrances shall be provided on all building facades. Such building facades shall be oriented to face the adjacent thoroughfare or open space, and shall be at ground level. Thoroughfares designated as alleys, lanes, bicycle trails, bicycle lanes, bicycle routes, paths, passages and transit routes are exempt from this requirement. 
b.  Primary facades for nonresidential uses shall be detailed as storefronts and glazed with clear glass no less than 60 percent of the length of the facade. 
c.  Primary facades for residential uses shall be detailed as residential windows and glazed with clear glass no less than 30 percent of the length of the facade. 
d.  The length of primary facades without intervening fenestration, architectural detailing or entryway shall not exceed 20 feet. 
e.  A maximum of 15 percent of fenestration treatment shall be permitted to utilize architectural detailing in place of glass materials to meet the fenestration treatment requirements. 
f.  Pedestrian entrances may be counted towards fenestration requirements. 
(3)  Building materials in non-rural areas. Exterior walls or facades visible from any thoroughfare shall utilize brick, glass, wood, stucco, stone or cement-based siding materials. Metal or metallic materials may be permitted but shall not constitute the majority of the material on any individual wall or facade. Thoroughfares designated as alleys, lanes, bicycle trails, bicycle lanes, bicycle routes, paths, passages and transit routes are exempt from this requirement. 
(4)  Urban design standards. 
a.  Delineation of building floors at the third story above ground level and lower shall be executed through windows, belt courses, cornice lines or similar architectural detailing. 
b.  The primary pedestrian access to all ground level uses and business establishments shall be directly accessible and visible from the sidewalk adjacent to the primary facade. 
c.  Drive-through service windows and associated elements, drives and surface parking facilities shall not be located between a building and any adjacent thoroughfare. 
d.  Buildings with switchboards, power generators, and other telecommunication relay equipment rooms located on the ground floor shall set back those uses for a minimum depth of 60 feet as measured from the building facade. 
e.  For the purposes of this subsection, individual nonresidential uses with more than 60,000 square feet of ground floor level floor area shall be defined as large scale nonresidential uses and shall meet the following additional regulations. 
1.  Such uses shall have their principal frontage only along boulevard or avenue thoroughfare types. 
2.  Such uses shall vary the roof and facade details, patterns and materials for each 300 feet of principal frontage building wall. 
3.  The total number of large scale nonresidential uses shall be limited to four such uses within individual HM districts, six within individual VL districts and ten within individual TN districts. 
(Ord. No. 15-05-137, § 3.3.3, 5-5-2015) 
Secs. 35-360—35-376. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - LANDSCAPING 

Sec. 35-377. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Landscape area means the area of a lot or parcel exclusive of building footprints, driveway, areas devoted to parking and walkway pavements devoted to plants, shrubs, trees and accessory ponds, pools and water features. 
Landscape strip means an area required by this chapter or by conditions of zoning that is reserved for the installation and/or maintenance of plant materials and/or street furniture. 
Native species means a plant occurring within the Piedmont region prior to foreign contact, according to the best scientific and historical documentation. This includes species that are considered indigenous, occurring in natural associations with habitats that existed prior to significant anthropogenic impacts and alteration to the landscape. 
Shrub means a deciduous or evergreen woody plant with single or multiple trunks or multiple leaders and with a mature height generally not expected to exceed 15 feet. 
Tree means any self-supporting, woody perennial plant usually having a single trunk diameter of three inches or more which normally attains a mature height of a minimum of 15 feet. 
Tree, shade, means a deciduous tree planted primarily for its overhead canopy and the quality of the shade it provides. 
Tree, specimen, means a particularly impressive or unusual example of a species due to its size, shade, age, or any other trait that epitomizes the character of the species. 
Tree, street, means a tree planted that is an element of a thoroughfare assembly. 
Tree, understory, means a small to medium size tree with an expected mature height less than 30 feet and a canopy which may or may not offer a sufficient clearance height for pedestrians beneath. 
Tree well means an area of soil around the trunk of a tree encompassing a minimum size of 25 square feet which may further be covered with a metal grating set flush with the adjacent sidewalk pavement. 
(Ord. No. 15-05-137, § 3.3.4.1, 5-5-2015) 
Sec. 35-378. - Landscape standards. 
The landscape standards in this article shall apply in the HM, VL, and TN districts. See section 35-401(d)(7) for parking lot landscaping requirements. 
(1)  Landscape design standards. 
a.  Native plants are preferred in all cases. In any case, noxious or invasive species are prohibited. 
b.  The spacing and placement of plants shall be adequate and appropriate for the typical size, shape and habit of the plant species at maturity. 
c.  Proposed trees and understory trees shall be centered horizontally; and minimally: 
1.  Two feet from walkways, curbing, and other impervious pavements when planted in a tree well or continuous planter; 
2.  Three feet from walkways, curbing and other impervious pavements when planted in a continuous swale; 
3.  Five feet from thoroughfare lights, underground utilities, utility meters and service lines, fences, walls and other ground level obstructions; 
4.  Six feet from porch eaves, and awnings and similar overhead obstructions associated with the ground level of buildings; 
5.  Eight feet from balconies, verandas, building eaves and cornices, and similar overhead obstructions associated with the upper stories of buildings. 
d.  Proposed trees shall be a minimum height of ten feet and/or three inches in caliper. 
e.  Proposed understory trees shall be a minimum of eight feet in height and/or 2½ inches in caliper. 
f.  Proposed shrubs shall be of a five-gallon container minimum. Shrubs shall be 18 inches to 24 inches minimum clear from any sidewalk or pavement edge at the lot line. 
g.  Ground vegetation or shrub plantings with spines, thorns or needles that may present hazards to pedestrians, bicyclists or vehicles are prohibited in the first two feet of the first layer. See Table 35-357. 
h.  Bare and exposed ground on the site and/or in landscaped areas shall be covered with live plant materials and/or mulch, with the following exceptions: 
1.  Naturally occurring dunes, creek beds/arroyos, rock outcroppings or similar landscape features typically lacking in vegetation. 
2.  Agricultural fields seasonally tilled for cultivation. 
3.  Hiking trails and/or traces. 
4.  Clay or sand surfaces associated with recreation fields and facilities. 
i.  Porous paving materials should be used to improve stormwater infiltration on site. 
j.  Artificial plants or artificial turf are prohibited, excluding active recreation fields that are typically subject to intense use and soil compaction which prohibits the establishment of turfgrass, and where paving or grass paving systems will not suffice given the area's purpose and level of use. 
k.  In non-rural areas, all required landscape areas shall be irrigated by an automatic underground irrigation system. 
1.  Where possible and practical, bubbler, drip irrigation, and soaker hose emitters shall be utilized. 
2.  Each irrigation system shall be equipped with a meter, backflow preventer, a rain sensor, and a suitable controller. 
l.  Constructed water features such as fountains, streams and ponds that operate with water recirculation systems shall be designed to prevent seepage and leaks. 
m.  Natural communities and/or areas of naturalized vegetation may be exempt from the installation of irrigation systems. 
n.  The size and limits of existing vegetation shall be indicated on the landscape plan. 
o.  Stormwater detention and retention ponds shall be integrated landscape features, rather than single-purpose flood control and stormwater management ponds. 
p.  Stormwater detention and retention ponds shall be planted with appropriate trees, shrubs and grasses. Plants in basin areas prone to submersion shall be hydrophilic. 
(2)  Landscape construction standards. 
a.  All plant materials shall meet with the minimum container size, class and other requirements outlined in American Standard for Nursery Stock (ANSI Z60.1-2004) published by the American Nursery and Landscape Association (ANLA). 
b.  Open spaces shall remain fenced and protected with a temporary construction/silt fence during all adjacent thoroughfare and site work and construction activities unless alterations to them are otherwise specified by the plans. 
c.  The soil structure of planting strips shall be protected from compaction with a temporary construction fence. Standards of access, excavation, movement, storage and backfilling of soils in relation to the construction and maintenance of deep utilities and manholes shall be specified. 
d.  The topsoil within the construction area's limits of disturbance shall be removed, stored and amended with organic soil additives as recommended by a landscape soils test prior to being redistributed. 
e.  Wind erosion shall be mitigated and controlled though dust abatement and similar practices during the period of site work and construction. 
f.  All landscape soils that have been compacted during construction activities shall be loosened, aerated, and reconditioned to a depth of at least six inches before planting to provide an arable topsoil layer that can support the long term health and vitality of landscaping. 
g.  Plants shall have normal, well-developed branches and vigorous root systems. 
h.  Temporary spray irrigation systems may be used to establish seeded areas for grass and groundcover. 
i.  Existing trees and vegetation should be preserved when possible. Such preservation may be used to fulfill the landscape requirements. 
j.  During construction, the root zones of existing trees and vegetation to be preserved shall be enclosed by a temporary protective fence and protected from clearing or construction activities. 
(3)  Landscape maintenance. 
a.  Native ground covers that do not require irrigation or fertilization are preferred. In any case, all grass and vegetation requiring fertilization shall be lightly fertilized to avoid fertilizer pollution to groundwater, streams and ponds. 
b.  No disturbed ground shall be left exposed. Turfgrass and other approved and appropriate groundcovers or mulch shall cover all non-paved and non-built developed areas. 
c.  It shall be the responsibility of the property owner or his assigned agent to: 
1.  Maintain and keep all screening and fencing in good condition at all times; 
2.  Maintain landscaping by keeping turfgrass lawns properly mowed and edged, plants properly pruned and disease-free, and planting beds mulched, groomed and weeded, except in the rural area, and other areas of naturally occurring vegetation and undergrowth; and 
3.  Replace any required plantings that are significantly damaged, missing, infested, disease-ridden, or dead, within one year or the next planting season, whichever occurs first, except in rural areas and areas of naturally occurring vegetation and undergrowth. 
(Ord. No. 15-05-137, § 3.3.4.2, 5-5-2015) 
Secs. 35-379—35-399. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - ADDITIONAL REQUIREMENTS 

Sec. 35-400. - Fences and walls. 
(a)  General. 
(1)  This section shall regulate permanent and temporary fences and walls. See outdoor dining supplemental use provisions in section 35-684 for regulations pertaining to fences and walls for outdoor dining when located within sidewalks. 
(2)  Fences and walls which conform to the provisions stated herein shall be permitted by the department of community development. Fences erected for agricultural uses listed in Table 35-595 shall be exempt from permit requirements. 
(3)  Heights of fences, walls, hedges, and other continuous foliage shall be measured from the adjacent top of the thoroughfare curb, surface of an alley, or the official established grade thereof, whichever is higher. Along interior lot lines, the measurement shall be from the average grade of the lot line of the parcel on which the fence is located. 
(4)  Fences, walls and vegetative materials must not obstruct the minimum sight distance requirements which are specified in the subdivision and land development ordinance administered by the director. 
(5)  The director may permit retaining wall heights in excess of the requirements of this section where existing topography so requires. 
(6)  Vehicle gates. 
a.  No part of a vehicle gate shall be located within 20 feet of a public right-of-way, nor shall any gate or vehicle in any way obstruct a public right-of-way, open space area or the minimum sight distance specified in the subdivision and land development ordinance regardless of whether open, closed or in an intermediate position. 
b.  Vehicle gates shall be further limited according to Table 35-400. 
(7)  Fences and walls shall be located a minimum of three feet from any public right-of-way. 
(b)  Materials and design. 
(1)  The use of broken glass, projecting nails, concertina wire, spikes or similar materials on fences and walls shall be prohibited. 
(2)  Barbed wire may only be used when associated with agricultural uses and shall be prohibited from use for any single-family uses. 
(3)  Walls and fences shall be limited to brick, wire, wood (or materials designed to have the appearance of natural wood) or stone materials. 
(4)  Fences and walls constructed along all property lines shall be constructed with a finished side toward any adjacent property. 
(5)  Street screens used for screening parking areas shall be located co-planar with the building facade line. 
(6)  Fence styles shall be further limited according to Table 35-400. 
(7)  Permanent fences and walls are prohibited directly beneath cantilevered portions of buildings. 
(8)  Only poles and beams shall be permitted to be located above the top of fences and walls and in excess of the established height limits of this section. Such vertical structures shall be: 
a.  A maximum width and depth of one foot by one foot; 
b.  Located a minimum distance of six feet from any other such vertical structure; and 
c.  Permitted to have a canopy affixed. See section 35-359(b)(3). 
(c)  Regulation based on location. 
(1)  Specific to rural areas. 
a.  Fences and walls shall be limited to four feet in height when located within the first layer, or when within any required buffer. 
b.  Fences and walls shall be limited to eight feet in height when located within any second or third layer, and when outside of any required buffer. 
c.  Transparent deer netting or similar materials are allowed up to 12 feet in height only when associated with uses delineated as agricultural in Table 35-595. 
(2)  Specific to non-rural areas. 
a.  For residential uses. 
1.  Fences and walls within the first layer shall be non-opaque. Opaque fences are permitted for all other locations. 
2.  Fence and wall heights shall be a maximum height of 42 inches in the first layer. 
3.  For all other locations fence and wall heights shall be a maximum of six feet. 
b.  For nonresidential uses. 
1.  Fences are prohibited in the first layer and between any building facade and an adjacent open space. 
2.  Wall heights shall be a maximum of three feet in the first layer and between any building facade and adjacent open space. 
3.  For all other locations fence and wall heights shall be a maximum of eight feet. 
Table 35-400. Fences and Walls 

 
P = Permitted (allowed) 
X = Not permitted 
L = Permitted (allowed) only in second or third layers (Table 35-357) 
R = Permitted (allowed) only for public recreational uses 
(Ord. No. 15-05-137, § 3.4.1, 5-5-2015) 
Sec. 35-401. - Parking and dumpsters. 
(a)  Parking for zoning districts. Areas dedicated to automobile parking shall be prohibited from being located between the primary facade and the adjacent sidewalk and thoroughfare. Off-street parking requirements for the individual zoning district shall be as set forth in Table 35-401. In the RL district, the table requirements shall be minimum required parking calculations. For all other districts, the table requirements shall be maximum off-street parking requirements. 
(b)  Off-site parking. Required parking shall be permitted to be located off-site, provided: 
(1)  Such parking provides safe and permissible pedestrian circulation and access between the principal structure and off-site parking facilities; and 
(2)  Such parking may not utilize parking spaces that are provided in satisfaction of minimum parking requirements for another parcel. 
Table 35-401. Parking Calculations 

 
(c)  Limitation on trucks and specialty equipment. 
(1)  Trucks and/or trailers exceeding four tons empty weight shall not be stored or parked in the rural areas, with the following exceptions: 
a.  Trucks used in farming the property on which they are located. 
b.  Trucks used in conjunction with a permitted use. 
c.  Trucks engaged in moving household goods or making deliveries. 
d.  A single tractor trailer may be parked at a residence if the owner and driver reside at the address, and it is parked on the buildable area of the lot, in the side or rear yard, no fewer than 200 feet from an off-site residence. 
(2)  Earth moving equipment, tractors or other heavy construction vehicles shall not be stored in rural areas, with the following exceptions: 
a.  During construction under an active building permit and/or land disturbance permit. 
b.  Equipment used in farming the property on which they are located. 
(3)  Recreational vehicles, campers, buses (including school buses), trailers, mobile home coaches, boats and boat trailers may be parked or stored in all districts only under the following conditions: 
a.  That such vehicles are not used as living quarters. 
b.  That the location of the parking or storage area shall be in the buildable area of the lot. 
(d)  Specific to non-rural areas. 
(1)  General. 
a.  Off-street parking or loading area shall not be used for the sale, repair, or dismantling of any vehicle or equipment, or for storage of materials or supplies, except when located within an enclosed garage. 
b.  All surface parking provided on site shall be oriented to the side or rear of the building. 
c.  No surface parking area shall be larger than 65,340 square feet unless separated by a thoroughfare, lane, alley or building. 
d.  On-street surface parking spaces located adjacent to the property line shall be counted toward the minimum number of parking spaces required for that lot. 
e.  Where possible, reverse entry angled on-street surface parking spaces are preferable to front entry orientation. 
f.  Porous paving materials are encouraged in order to increase stormwater infiltration on site. 
(2)  Loading. 
a.  All proposed uses shall provide to the director documentation of all proposed loading areas including information on how such access will ensure vehicular and pedestrian safety. 
b.  Loading areas, service yards, mechanical and electrical equipment and other utilities, including roof-top equipment, shall be screened with evergreen plant material, opaque fences, or structural screens of materials and design matching the exterior building facades. 
c.  On-street loading and servicing zones shall be permitted, provided travel lanes are not used for such purposes. Such on-street loading and servicing zone shall be limited to a maximum of 40 feet per individual block face. 
d.  On-site, off-street loading and service areas shall be at the third layer as indicated in Table 35-357, shall be accessed from alleys when available, and shall be prohibited from facing commercial streets, boulevards or avenues. 
(3)  Dumpsters. 
a.  Dumpsters shall be placed on concrete pads of sufficient size and strength to support the weight of service vehicles. Restaurants and eateries shall place dumpsters on concrete pads that are designed to slope into a drain that is equipped with a grease trap. 
b.  Dumpster areas, shall be screened with evergreen plant material, opaque fences, or structural screens of materials and design matching the exterior building facades. 
(4)  Off-street bicycle parking. 
a.  Off-street bicycle parking shall be provided at a minimum of one bicycle parking space for every ten vehicular spaces provided, with a minimum of one such space being required. 
b.  After the first 50 required bicycle spaces are provided, additional spaces may be reduced by one-half. 
c.  Required bicycle parking shall be provided in a safe, accessible and convenient location in relation to the pedestrian entrances of the uses that the parking is provided for. 
(5)  Drives and curb cuts. 
a.  When located along highway, boulevard or avenue thoroughfares, curb cuts are prohibited. 
b.  On all other thoroughfares, curb cuts shall be permitted at a maximum width of 24 feet. 
c.  Curb cuts shall be located a minimum distance of 100 feet from any other curb cut. 
d.  Driveways and drop-offs may be located within the first layer. See Table 35-357. 
(6)  Parking decks and structures. 
a.  Parking decks must include a minimum of 25 percent of occupiable floor area (nonresidential) at ground level and the occupiable floor area must be a minimum depth of 60 feet. 
b.  Parking decks shall be constructed to conceal vehicles. 
c.  Parking deck levels shall be predominantly horizontal and flat. 
d.  Parking decks shall include architectural detailing and finish compatible with surrounding buildings. 
e.  Parking deck entrances for pedestrians shall be directly from a sidewalk or path. 
(7)  Site design. 
a.  Off-street parking spaces shall be located with sufficient room for safe and convenient parking without infringing on any public thoroughfare, open space or sidewalk. 
b.  Parking areas on adjoining lots may share curb cuts, driveways and parking spaces subject to a recorded covenant running with the property on which the facilities are located. 
c.  All developments shall have pedestrian walkways a minimum width of five feet connecting ground level parking lots or decks to the adjacent sidewalks, open spaces and building entrances. 
d.  Parking areas that exceed 120 spaces shall include a minimum eight-foot-wide pedestrian walkway. The pavements of such walkways shall be differentiated from parking area pavement through a change in surface texture, material, style, and/or color. 
e.  Parking lots provided as a principal use of property, passenger car rental uses or motor vehicle sales uses shall limit impervious pavement to a maximum of 40 percent of the area utilized for parking. 
(8)  Landscaping and screening. 
a.  When surface parking abuts a thoroughfare right-of-way: 
1.  A street screen shall screen the parking area, at a minimum height of two feet and a maximum height of three feet; or 
2.  A minimum four-foot-wide landscape area shall screen the parking area. within the landscape area, a continuous planting of evergreen shrubs is to be installed at a minimum height of two feet and maintained to a maximum height of four feet. 
b.  Parking lots shall provide minimum ten-foot-wide landscape islands at the end of each parking bay. Such islands shall have a minimum of one tree with a planting area a minimum area of 50 square feet and a minimum width of five feet and shall be planted or covered with other landscape materials. 
c.  Parking rows with more than five parking spaces shall provide an additional landscape island for every six spaces in the row. 
d.  The landscape islands shall be distributed throughout the lot and may be incorporated as a component of a stormwater management plan to facilitate water harvesting. 
e.  Landscape islands may be omitted for solar panel installations or other shading structures of equal or greater coverage. 
f.  All required trees shall be minimum three-inch caliper when planted and shall be of a native shade tree variety which shall attain a minimum mature crown spread greater than 15 feet. A pre-approved list of native shade trees is available from the director. 
(9)  Electric vehicle accommodation. 
a.  Parking lots over a half acre in size shall include two electric car recharging stations for each half acre of parking or portion thereof. For the purposes of this provision, the parking area of a parking deck shall include all surfaces to which vehicles have access. 
b.  Where golf cart parking is allowed on the street, a GFCI outlet shall be installed on the street side of the curb or in the curb in order to eliminate the hazard of extension cords across the sidewalk. The outlet may be controlled by a switch inside the adjacent building. 
(Ord. No. 15-05-137, § 3.4.2, 5-5-2015; Ord. No. 15-10-146, § 2, 10-6-2015) 
Sec. 35-402. - Inoperative vehicles. 
(a)  Any automobile, truck, vehicle or trailer of any kind or type, which is inoperable, are hereby found to create a condition tending to reduce the value of private property, to promote blight and deterioration, and invite plundering and vandalism, to create fire hazards, to constitute an attractive nuisance creating a hazard to the health and safety of minors, to create a harborage for rodents and insects, and to be injurious to the health, safety and general welfare and, when on city thoroughfares, to create a traffic hazard and endanger public safety. 
(b)  Such inoperable vehicles shall not be parked or stand on any private property or public thoroughfares, with the following limited exceptions. 
(1)  Such inoperable vehicles shall be permitted when located behind and fully screened from view of any public right-of-way by permissible fences or walls shall be permitted. 
(2)  A maximum of two such inoperable vehicles shall be permitted on an individual lot when used as rural ornamentation in the RL district. 
(c)  This section shall not be the exclusive regulation of abandoned, wrecked, dismantled, or inoperative vehicles or contrivances within the incorporated limits of the city, but shall be supplemental and in addition to the other regulations and regulatory codes, statutes, or provisions of law heretofore and hereinafter enacted by city, county, state, or other legal entity or agency having jurisdiction. 
(Ord. No. 15-05-137, § 3.4.3, 5-5-2015) 
Sec. 35-403. - Outdoor storage. 
(a)  Outdoor storage is permitted in side and rear yards only, and shall be screened so as to prevent visibility from residential uses, thoroughfares and open spaces. 
(b)  Outdoor displays for merchandise which is being offered for sale on premises shall be permitted for nonresidential uses, provided all associated devices or structures: 
(1)  Shall not be permanently secured to the ground; and 
(2)  Shall meet all applicable provisions of this chapter when located within open spaces and sidewalks. 
(Ord. No. 15-05-137, § 3.4.4, 5-5-2015) 
Sec. 35-404. - Cemeteries. 
In a parcel with a cemetery, burial ground, human remains or burial objects, there shall be no land disturbing activity or timbering unless approved by the department of community development. The person or entity seeking a permit shall also comply with O.C.G.A. § 36-72-4. If a parcel is adjacent to a cemetery, there shall be no land disturbance in that parcel unless approved by the department of community development. The following development standards shall be required as a part of the application process for a land disturbance permit or building permit on any parcel with a cemetery or within 50 feet on any parcel adjacent to a cemetery: 
(1)  A report prepared by an archeologist determining the boundary of the cemetery and stating the number of graves believed to be present and their location as can be determined from the use of minimally invasive investigation techniques, including remote sensing methods and the use of metal probes. 
(2)  A survey of the cemetery prepared by or under the direction of a registered surveyor showing the location of the boundaries of the cemetery or burial ground based on an archeologist's report. 
(3)  A 25-foot natural undisturbed buffer with a ten-foot improvement setback shall be provided around the perimeter of the outermost burials, as determined by an archeologist, if a cemetery is located on the parcel of land to be developed. If a cemetery is within 25 feet of the parcel to be developed, a 25-foot natural undisturbed buffer with a ten-foot improvement setback shall be provided along common property lines on the parcel where the land disturbance permit or building permit is being sought. 
(4)  A temporary tree protection fence shall be installed on the outer perimeter of the 25-foot undisturbed buffer before any land disturbing activity occurs. If the cemetery is located on an adjacent parcel, the tree protection fence shall be located along common property lines. The temporary tree protection fence shall remain in place until construction is completed. 
(5)  A permanent four-foot-high fence or wall with a gate compliant with this chapter shall be constructed along the perimeter of a cemetery on a parcel for which land disturbing activity is sought. The location of the fence shall be as determined by an archaeologist. If the cemetery is located on an adjacent parcel, the fence shall be located interior to the required buffer and improvement setback or along the common property lines as may be approved by the city arborist. The gate shall have a latch and be four feet wide if the cemetery is inactive or ten feet wide if active. 
(6)  Uninhibited daylight access to the cemetery shall be provided via a 20-foot graveled easement to the cemetery from the nearest public road. The easement shall be recorded in the county courthouse. 
(7)  A maintenance plan for a cemetery located on the parcel for which a land disturbance permit or building permit is sought shall be developed and implemented. 
(8)  The location of a cemetery, as identified by the surveyor, shall be included on the recorded plat. 
(9)  A small plaque/marker with the name of the cemetery, range of burials and any other historical information may be placed on the cemetery fence. 
(Ord. No. 15-05-137, § 3.4.5, 5-5-2015) 
Sec. 35-405. - Nuisance. 
No person shall cause or permit on property a nuisance affecting public health. The following are potential nuisances affecting public health and shall be prohibited: 
(1)  Cesspools. Cesspools or septic tanks which are in an unsanitary condition or which cause an offensive odor. 
(2)  Dangerous animals. No owner or person in charge of an animal shall permit an animal which is dangerous to the public health or safety to be exposed in public. 
(3)  Odor. Premises which are in such a state or condition as to cause an offensive odor or which are in an unsanitary condition. 
(4)  Stagnant water. Water which affords a breeding place for mosquitoes and other insect pests. 
(5)  Water pollution. Pollution of a body of water, well, spring, stream, drainage ditch or surface drainage by sewage, industrial wastes, or other substances placed in or near the water in a manner that will cause harmful material to pollute the water. 
(Ord. No. 15-05-137, § 3.4.6, 5-5-2015) 
Sec. 35-406. - Night sky. 
(a)  General. 
(1)  Purpose and intent. The purpose and intent of this section is to provide a regulatory strategy for outdoor lighting that will permit reasonable uses of outdoor lighting for nighttime safety, utility, security, productivity, enjoyment and commerce; curtail and reverse the degradation of the nighttime visual environment and the night sky; preserve the dark night sky for astronomy; minimize glare, obtrusive light and artificial sky glow by limiting outdoor lighting that is misdirected, excessive or unnecessary; conserve energy and resources to the greatest extent possible; and help to protect the natural environment from the damaging effects of night lighting from manmade sources. 
(2)  Conformance with applicable codes. All outdoor illuminating devices shall be installed in conformance with the provisions of this section, the building code and the electrical code as applicable and under appropriate permit and inspection. Where there is conflict between the provisions of this section and other regulations, the most restrictive provision shall prevail. 
(3)  Applicability. For all land uses, developments and buildings that require a permit, all outdoor lighting fixtures shall meet the requirements of this section. All building additions or modifications of 25 percent or more in terms of additional dwelling units, gross floor area, or parking spaces, either with a single addition or with cumulative additions subsequent to the effective date of this provision, shall invoke the requirements of this section for the entire property, including previously installed and any new outdoor lighting. Cumulative modification or replacement of outdoor lighting constituting 60 percent or more of the permitted lumens for the parcel, no matter the actual amount of lighting already on a non-conforming site, shall constitute a major addition for purposes of this section. 
(4)  Minor additions. Additions or modifications of less than 25 percent to existing uses, as defined in subsection (a)(3) of this section, and that require a permit, shall require the submission of a complete inventory and site plan detailing all existing and any proposed new outdoor lighting. Any new lighting on the site shall meet the requirements of this section with regard to shielding and lamp type. 
(5)  Exempt lighting. The following luminaries and lighting systems are exempt from these requirements: 
a.  Lighting for pools used at night, controlled by timers and with dimmers; 
b.  Underwater lighting used for the illumination of swimming pools and fountains, controlled by timers and with dimmers; 
c.  Temporary holiday lighting (may be used no more than 60 days per lot per year); 
d.  Lighting required and regulated by the Federal Aviation Administration, or other federal, state or local agency; 
e.  Emergency lighting used by police, fire, or medical personnel, or at their direction; 
f.  All outdoor light fixtures producing light directly from the combustion of fossil fuels, such as kerosene and gasoline when used for construction or similar temporary activities; 
g.  Security lighting controlled and activated by a motion sensor device for a duration of five minutes or less. 
(6)  Prohibited lighting. The following lighting systems are prohibited: 
a.  Aerial lasers; 
b.  Searchlight style lights; 
c.  Other very intense lighting, defined as having a light source exceeding 200,000 lumens or intensity in any direction of 2,000,000 candelas or more, except as used by police, fire, or medical personnel, or at their direction; 
d.  Mercury vapor lamps; 
e.  Neon lighting not located in HM, VL, or TN districts and not on commercial street, avenue or boulevard thoroughfare types; 
f.  Neon lighting that is not full cutoff in any location. 
(b)  Outdoor lighting standards. All nonexempt outdoor lighting fixtures shall meet the following criteria: 
(1)  Shall be full cutoff placed so as to allow no light above the horizontal as measured at the luminaire, except as herein noted in this section (as in the case of period fixtures, cutoff fixtures may be used). 
(2)  Shall be located, aimed or shielded so as to minimize glare and stray light trespassing across property boundaries and into the public right-of-way. 
(3)  Commercial parking areas. 
a.  All lighting fixtures servicing parking lots, except floodlights, shall be cutoff fixtures, directed downward and not toward buildings or other areas. 
b.  The minimum illumination level for a parking lot shall be 0.4 footcandles at grade level and the ratio of the average illumination to the minimum illumination shall not exceed 4:1. 
c.  Floodlights should be aimed or shielded to minimize uplight. 
d.  Light poles used in parking lots shall not exceed 35 feet in height. 
(4)  In cases of off-street parking lots, shall be located, aimed or shielded so as to minimize glare and stray light trespassing across property boundaries and into the public right of way in accordance with the following standards: 
Table 35-406. Parking Lot Lighting Standards 

 
(5)  Flood or spot lamps must be positioned no higher than 45 degrees above straight down (half-way between the vertical and the horizontal) when the source is visible from any off-site residential property or public roadway. 
(6)  All light fixtures that are required to be shielded shall be installed and maintained in such a manner that the shielding is effective as described herein for fully shielded fixtures. 
(7)  Multi-use development lighting must conform to the standards of its respective use. 
(8)  Illumination levels are measured from any height and orientation of the measuring device at any location along the property line, except the lighting of parking lots shall be measured at grade with the meter sensor held horizontally on the surface. 
(9)  Street lights. All street light fixtures new, repaired (outside of normal maintenance) or replaced fixtures shall be full cutoff. 
(c)  Special uses. All lighting not directly associated with the special use areas designated below shall conform to the lighting standards described in this section. 
(1)  Outdoor sports, recreation fields, or performance areas. Lighting of outdoor recreational facilities (public or private), such as, but not limited to, outdoor athletic fields, courts, tracks, special event or show areas shall meet the following requirements: 
a.  Facilities designed for municipal leagues, elementary to high school levels of play and training fields for recreational or social levels of play, college play, semi-professional, professional or national levels of play shall utilize luminaries with minimal uplight consistent with the illumination constraints of the design. Where fully shielded fixtures are not utilized, acceptable luminaries shall include those which: 
1.  Are provided with internal and/or external glare control louvers or lenses, and are installed so as to minimize uplight and off-site light trespass and glare; and 
2.  Are installed and maintained so as to avoid aiming no more than 2.5 times the mounting height. 
b.  Illuminance. All lighting installations shall be designed to achieve the illuminance levels for the activity as recommended by the Illuminating Engineering Society of North America (IESNA RP-6). 
c.  Off-site spill. The installation shall also limit off-site spill (off the parcel containing the sports facility) to the maximum extent possible consistent with the illumination constraints of the design. For all recreational or social levels of play and training fields, as well as, performance areas, illumination levels shall not exceed 1.5 footcandles at any location along any nonresidential property line, and 0.5 footcandles at any location along any residential property line. 
d.  Curfew. All events shall be scheduled so as to complete all activity no later than 10:30 p.m. Illumination of the playing field, court or track shall be permitted after the curfew only to conclude a scheduled event that was unable to conclude before the curfew due to unusual circumstances. Field lighting for these facilities shall be turned off within 30 minutes after the last event of the night. 
e.  Setback. All light poles shall be set back the greater of 50 feet or one foot for every foot in height from any residential property line or right-of-way. 
(2)  Service station canopies and parking structures. 
a.  All luminaries mounted on or recessed into the lower surface of service station canopies and parking structures shall be fully shielded and utilize flat lenses. 
b.  The total light output of luminaries mounted on the lower surface, or recessed into the lower surface of the canopy, and any lighting within signage or illuminated panels over the pumps, shall not exceed 50 footcandles. 
c.  The total light output of illuminated areas of a service station other than as detailed in b, above, shall not exceed 15 footcandles. 
d.  Illuminance levels for the interior of parking structures, where interior lighting is visible from outside the structure, shall conform to the IESNA recommendation (RP-20). 
e.  Lights shall not be mounted on the top or sides of a canopy and the sides of a canopy shall not be illuminated. 
(3)  Security lighting. 
a.  Security lighting shall be directed toward the targeted area. 
b.  Sensor activated lighting must be located in such a manner as to prevent direct glare and lighting into properties of others or into a public right-of-way, and the light shall not be triggered by activity off the property. Such lighting shall be controlled and activated by a motion sensor device for a duration of five minutes or less. 
(4)  Pedestrian path lighting. Lighting post shall not exceed 16 feet from the finished grade. 
(5)  Architectural accent lighting. 
a.  Fixtures used to accent architectural features, materials, colors, style of buildings, landscaping, or art shall be located, aimed and shielded so that light is directed only on those features. Such fixtures shall be aimed or shielded to minimize light spill into the dark night sky in conformance with the luminaire standards. 
b.  Lighting fixtures shall not generate glare, or direct light beyond the facade onto a neighboring property, streets or into the night sky. 
(6)  Temporary lighting permits. 
a.  Permits for temporary lighting will be granted by the department if the total output from the luminaries does not exceed 50 footcandles and the following conditions apply: 
1.  The purpose for which the lighting is proposed can be completed within 30 days, except that the permit for a major construction project may extend to completion. 
2.  The proposed lighting is designed in such a manner as to minimize light trespass and glare. 
3.  Permits issued for temporary recreational lighting shall be extinguished within an hour of the permitted end of the event. 
b.  The application for the temporary lighting permit shall include, but not be limited to, the following information: 
1.  Name and address of applicant and property owner; 
2.  Location of proposed luminaire; 
3.  Date and times for the lighting; 
4.  Type, wattage and lumen output of lamp; 
5.  Type and shielding of proposed luminaries; 
6.  Intended use of the lighting; 
7.  Duration of time for requested exemption; 
8.  The nature of the exemption; and 
9.  The means to minimize light trespass and glare. 
(d)  Variances. 
(1)  Any person may submit an application to the city council for a variance from the provisions of this section. The application should include, but not be limited to, evidence about the following: 
a.  How the proposed design and appearance of the luminaire are superior; 
b.  How light trespass, uplighting and glare will be limited 
c.  How the proposed solution will provide a benefit without negative impact on the health, safety, or welfare of the community. 
(2)  The application may include the recommended practices of the Illuminating Engineering Society of North America, a professional engineer, or other authority on outdoor lighting. 
(e)  Submission of plans and evidence of compliance. 
(1)  The applicant for any permit required by any provision of the laws of the city in connection with proposed work involving outdoor lighting fixtures shall submit, as part of the application for permit, evidence that the proposed work will comply with this section. Even should no other such permit be required, the installation or modification (except for routine servicing and same-type lamp replacement of any exterior lighting) shall require submission of the information described below. The submission shall contain, but shall not necessarily be limited to, the following, all or part of which may be part or in addition to the information required elsewhere in the laws of the city upon application for the required permit: 
a.  Plans indicating the location on the premises of each illuminating device, both proposed and any already existing on the site. 
b.  Description of all illuminating devices, fixtures, lamps, supports, reflectors, both proposed and existing. The description may include, but is not limited to, catalog cuts and illustrations by manufacturers. 
c.  Photometric data, such as that furnished by manufacturers or similar, showing the angle of cut off of light emissions. 
(2)  Additional submission. The above required plans, descriptions and data shall be sufficiently complete to enable the department to readily determine whether compliance with the requirements of this section will be secured. If such plans, descriptions and data cannot enable this ready determination, the applicant shall additionally submit as evidence of compliance to enable such determination such certified reports of tests as will do so provided that these tests shall have been performed and certified by a recognized testing laboratory. 
(3)  Subdivision plats. All new subdivided properties shall submit information as described herein for installed street lights and other common or public area outdoor lighting. 
(4)  Certification. For all projects, certification that the lighting as installed, conforms to the approved plans shall be provided by an illumination engineer/professional before the certificate of occupancy is issued. Until this certification is submitted, approval for use by the issuance of the certificate of occupancy shall not be issued. 
(Ord. No. 15-05-137, § 3.4.7, 5-5-2015) 
Secs. 35-407—35-425. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 6. - DENSITY CONTROLS 

Sec. 35-426. - Purpose. 
The following density control regulations shall govern development within the city. 
(Ord. No. 15-05-137, § 3.5, 5-5-2015) 
Sec. 35-427. - Density unit allocation. 
(a)  The density unit allocation table (Table 35-427) sets forth the allowable square footages for respective uses based on the number of density units provided. 
(b)  Uses listed in Table 35-427 are only permitted according to the permissible densities designated for individual zoning districts in Table 35-461. 
(c)  Uses listed in Table 35-427 are only permitted for the permitted principal uses designated for individual zoning districts in Table 35-595. 
(d)  Density unit allocation calculations are not required for the allocation of accessory dwellings, agricultural uses with less than 25,000 square feet of floor area or for accessory uses containing no floor area. 
Table 35-427. Density Unit Allocation 

 
;hn0; (Ord. No. 15-05-137, § 3.5(A), 5-5-2015) 
Sec. 35-428. - Baseline density. 
Base density is delineated in Table 35-461. 
(Ord. No. 15-05-137, § 3.5(B), 5-5-2015) 
Sec. 35-429. - Minimum density.
