For zoning districts that have a minimum density greater than baseline density, as presented in Table 35-461, the additional density above baseline density shall be required to be entitled according to the methods described in the transferable development rights ordinance in article II of chapter 14. 
(Ord. No. 15-05-137, § 3.5(C), 5-5-2015) 
Sec. 35-430. - Additional density. 
Additional density units for a property may only be added in excess of the baseline density when a property is located within an individual zoning district that enables density greater than the baseline density (Table 35-461) and whenever a property utilizes any of the following procedures for obtaining increased density units: 
(1)  The transfer of development rights. Article II of chapter 14 further establishes the transferable development rights provisions governing the ability to relocate density unit permission from parcel to parcel within the city; 
(2)  Increased open space. The allocation of additional open space within individual HM-SD, HM-MDR, HM-MU, VL and TN zoning districts shall enable a density unit increase equal to one percent of the baseline density for each one percent of additional open space that is provided in an amount greater than the open space calculation in Table 35-461. 
(3)  Civic uses. City halls, fire stations, police stations, libraries, and museums shall qualify for addition density as further regulated herein: 
a.  Such uses must be agreed to be operated or managed by the city; 
b.  The floor area for such uses shall: 
1.  Be permitted to be exempt from density calculations of the individual zoning district; 
2.  Enable an additional one square foot of additional density permitted within the individual zoning district for every one square foot of such use provided; and 
3.  Remain any of the identified civic uses for a minimum of five years. 
(Ord. No. 15-05-137, § 3.5(D), 5-5-2015) 
Secs. 35-431—35-458. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 7. - DISTRICT CONTROLS 

Sec. 35-459. - Purpose. 
The following district control regulations shall govern development within each applicable district. 
(Ord. No. 15-05-137, § 3.6, 5-5-2015) 
Sec. 35-460. - Additional zoning district provisions. 
(a)  RL districts. RL districts may be subdivided as three development types: single lot, minor subdivision and farmette development types. Such development types shall comply with the city subdivision code and the development controls established in Table 35-461, as well as all other regulations in this chapter. 
(b)  Additional HM district provisions. HM districts subdistricts shall be further regulated as follows: 
(1)  All HM subdistricts shall meet all regulations of this chapter that apply to HM districts. 
(2)  HM-LDR subdistricts may utilize individual lot sewage systems. Such subdistricts shall be further limited to permit only those uses designated as agricultural or residential uses for the HM district in Table 35-595. 
(3)  HM-MDR subdistricts shall be predominantly residential allowing those uses designated for the HM district in Table 35-595. 
(4)  HM-SD subdistricts shall only be utilized for specialized HM districts that are further designated as special districts. Such subdistricts shall be utilized to promote the purposes set forth in the comprehensive plan and other officially adopted plans of the city and shall be further regulated and delineated as set forth in division 8 of this article. 
(5)  HM-MU subdistricts shall be mixed use. Such subdistricts shall allow those uses designated for the HM district in Table 35-595. 
(Ord. No. 15-05-137, § 3.6(A), 5-5-2015) 
Sec. 35-461. - Development controls. 
(a)  The development controls table in subsection (d) of this section sets forth the space dimensions required for each zoning district and subdistrict. 
(b)  In order to develop at densities greater than the baseline density, the methods described in section 35-430 shall be used. 
(c)  Definitions. Calculations within Table 35-461 in subsection (d) of this section shall be further defined as follows: 
Acreage maximum means the maximum total acreage required to be provided within each individual zoning district. 
Acreage minimum means the minimum total acreage required to be provided within each individual zoning district. 
Baseline density means the number of density units per acre of property within each individual zoning district for all approved uses, as regulated by Table 35-461 in subsection (d) of this section, before the application of any transferable development rights, density transfer credits, or density bonuses. Actual development densities may be higher, up to the development per acre maximum using the methods described in the TDR ordinance in chapter 14, article II, or lower. 
Density per acre maximum means the maximum total number of density units that are permitted for every one acre of property within each individual zoning district for all approved uses. 
Nonresidential density maximum means the maximum percentage of allowable density units permitted to be provided within each individual zoning district for uses listed in Table 35-595 that are not designated as agricultural or residential uses. 
Nonresidential density minimum means the minimum percentage of allowable density units required to be provided within each individual zoning district for uses listed in Table 35-595 that are not designated as agricultural or residential uses. 
Open space minimum means the minimum amount of land area within the individual zoning district required to be open space (see article VI, division 4 of this chapter). Land permanently protected by a conservation easement prior to being rezoned into an HM, VL, TN, or PC district shall not be included in calculations of open space required or of open space provided. 
(d)  See division 3 of this article for additional provisions for primary facade setback, side yard setback, rear yard setback, lot area, building height and frontage buildout. 
Table 35-461. Development Controls Table 

 
;hn0; (Ord. No. 15-05-137, § 3.6(B), 5-5-2015) 
Sec. 35-462. - Mixed use concurrency. 
Residential uses and nonresidential uses shall have additional requirements of concurrency when such uses are provided within individual HM-MU, VL and TN zoning districts and as further regulated herein. 
(Ord. No. 15-05-137, § 3.6(C), 5-5-2015) 
Sec. 35-463. - Provision for transit. 
Each VL or TN district shall reserve a transit station site, for service to that district, along with a transit corridor linking the transit station site to the South Fulton Parkway Right-of-Way corridor, according to the requirements found in chapter 26. 
(Ord. No. 15-05-137, § 3.6(D), 5-5-2015) 
Sec. 35-464. - District expansion. 
In order for a zoning district to expand and incorporate neighboring properties that, alone, do not meet the minimum requirements of the district, the following rules shall be met: 
(1)  The proposed district expansion shall be master planned: The applicant shall submit a site plan and other application materials that demonstrate that the project complements and is in harmony with the existing district. 
(2)  The site plan and other application materials for the proposed district expansion shall be reviewed by the homeowner's association of the existing district; the HOA shall make a recommendation to the planning commission and the city council as to the appropriateness of the district expansion plan. The planning commission and the city council shall consider the recommendation in the approval or denial of the application. 
(3)  Entitlements. Only the density units that are available with the expansion property shall accrue to that property. Unused density units that are available based on the district-wide baseline density or the district-wide maximum density shall be applied to the expansion property only by agreement with the HOA. Additional development rights may be transferred in accordance with the TDR program, as described in chapter 14. 
(4)  All provisions of Table 35-461 related to density per acre, nonresidential density, and open space shall be calculated and applied internally to the proposed expansion, and independent of the existing district. 
(Ord. No. 15-05-137, § 3.6(E), 5-5-2015) 
Secs. 35-465—35-481. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 8. - PC, PARKWAY COMMERCIAL DISTRICT 

Sec. 35-482. - PC, Parkway Commercial District. 
The regulations set forth herein are the regulations for the parkway commercial district. 
(Ord. No. 15-05-137, § 3.7, 5-5-2015) 
Sec. 35-483. - Statement of intent. 
The purpose and intent of establishing the PC, Parkway Commercial District is as follows: 
(1)  Provide opportunities for appropriately scaled commercial development for the rural areas of the city outside of the hamlet, village, and town districts; 
(2)  Prohibit or place reasonable controls on the development of inappropriate large scale highway-oriented retail, service, office and dining uses which are intended to serve larger areas of the city than the rural area of this community; 
(3)  Alleviate development pressure on the surrounding rural area by placing reasonable controls on development and expansion of strip commercial uses; 
(4)  Improve the quality of air and water in commercial areas through provisions for the planting of trees, greenspace protection, bicycle parking and electric vehicle parking; 
(5)  Encourage a grid of connected thoroughfares to improve access and reduce congestion; 
(6)  Facilitate safe, attractive and convenient pedestrian circulation and minimize conflicts between pedestrians and vehicles; 
(7)  Encourage pedestrian flow through the design of buildings with ground level uses; 
(8)  Improve pedestrian access within the district and to and from the surrounding areas; 
(9)  Establish building facade lines and sidewalk requirements, and reserve the space between buildings and the thoroughfare for pedestrian functions; 
(10)  Provide services to the residents of the rural areas of the city and prevent commercial development that is inappropriate for its rural context; and 
(11)  To meet these needs in a fashion that supports the rural vision and brand as expressed in the city's adopted comprehensive plan. 
(Ord. No. 15-05-137, § 3.7(A), 5-5-2015) 
Sec. 35-484. - Incorporation of general regulations. 
The general regulations found in this chapter for HM-MU districts are applicable to this district except where specific regulations are further established for this Parkway Commercial District below. 
(1)  Only the following uses shall be permitted, and only to the degree listed, for HM districts in Table 35-595: 
a.  Agricultural uses. 
b.  Retail uses. 
c.  Gas stations (all pumps must be behind building). 
d.  Services uses. 
e.  Office, professional as listed in technical uses. 
f.  Places of worship, as listed in arts, entertainment and recreation uses. 
g.  Restaurants and eateries, as listed in accommodation and food service uses. 
h.  Residential uses. 
(2)  Residential uses shall be regulated consistent with the RL district. 
(3)  As defined in section 35-461, baseline density shall be one unit per acre, density per acre maximum shall be one unit per acre, nonresidential density maximum shall be 100 percent, and minimum open space shall be 70 percent. 
(4)  Minimum lot size shall be four acres. 
(5)  Preservation open space shall not be transferred off-site, and shall not be transferred from off-site. 
(6)  Rear yard setbacks for nonresidential uses shall be ten feet. Side yard setbacks for nonresidential uses shall be ten feet when adjacent to open space, and zero feet when adjacent to another nonresidential use. 
(7)  Single-family detached uses on individual lots shall not be required to provide open space or buffers. This exemption shall not apply to single-family detached uses that are a part of a master planned development including multiple subdivided lots. 
(Ord. No. 15-05-137, § 3.7(B), 5-5-2015) 
Sec. 35-485. - District size and location. 
(a)  The maximum size of a PC district is 12 acres. 
(b)  No structures within any PC district shall lie more than 1,000 feet from the right-of-way of South Fulton Parkway, or more than 1,000 feet from the right-of-way of any street intersecting with South Fulton Parkway. 
(c)  Maximum total commercial floor area shall be 10,000 square feet per district. 
(d)  PC districts may be incorporated into future contiguous/adjacent HM, VL, and TN districts. In such cases, the buffers between those districts may be relieved, and the PC district will be governed by the criteria for the applicable HM, VL, and TN district. 
(Ord. No. 15-05-137, § 3.7(C), 5-5-2015) 
Sec. 35-486. - Establishment of form and design controls. 
The following regulations shall govern the form and design of development in the PC district: 
(1)  All structures and improvements shall be architecturally consistent with historic rural vernacular styles common in the Piedmont or southeastern region of the United States. Approval may be contingent on proof of such consistency, as determined by approval of the director, planning commission, and city council. 
(2)  Vehicular access shall be derived from internal thoroughfares and all buildings shall front internal thoroughfares. District entrances shall be derived only from Campbellton-Redwine Road, Capps Ferry Road, Rico Road, or Cochran Mill Road. No more than one entrance shall be permitted per 700 feet of street frontage. Both vehicular and pedestrian interparcel access shall be provided among adjacent properties. Driveways, parking lots, and pedestrian access shall be shared. Direct thoroughfare connections shall be provided for both vehicular and pedestrian access to adjacent HM, VL, or TN districts. 
(3)  Site design shall minimize cut-and-fill and maximize tree preservation in siting of buildings, drives, and parking facilities. The city arborist shall review tree preservation plans. 
(4)  Building height shall be limited to a maximum of 35 feet. 
(5)  Internal frontages shall be detailed with street trees and street parking, along with architecturally-consistent street furniture, including pedestrian lighting, benches, trash receptacles, and bicycle racks. 

(6)  All buildings and parking facilities within the district shall be connected by sidewalks with a minimum width of eight feet. 
(7)  The district's pedestrian network shall be extended to the edges of the district to provide opportunities for connection to existing or planned path networks. 
(8)  The district site plan shall include a location for a grease trap for any use which anticipates cooking. 
(9)  PC districts may use well and septic. 
(Ord. No. 15-05-137, § 3.7(D), 5-5-2015) 
Secs. 35-487—35-510. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 9. - SPECIAL DISTRICTS: GENERAL 

Sec. 35-511. - Creation of special districts. 
These regulations permit the creation of HM-SD districts only in areas which meet the following requirements: 
(1)  Are designated as a special district on the future development map of the comprehensive plan; 
(2)  Are in accord with and serve to promote the purposes set forth in the comprehensive plan and other officially adopted plans of the city in accordance with the comprehensive plan; 
(3)  Encourage land use and development in substantial accord with the physical design set forth in the comprehensive plan and other official adopted plans of the city; 
(4)  Are officially designated as having special and substantial public interest in protection of an existing or proposed unique character including, as appropriate, surrounding such areas, and/or a high economic value to the city; 
(5)  Contribute to the open space protections of the comprehensive plan at levels similar to other current districts; 
(6)  Repeal and replace existing zoning regulations, for the accomplishment of special public purposes for which the district was established in cases where special and substantial public interest requires such modification of existing zoning regulations; 
(7)  Documented through public processes of being eligible to support a mixture of uses, densities and/or development characteristics that are not as easily facilitated in other zoning districts; 
(8)  All of the parcels of the individual district shall be contiguous and located within the boundary of the individual district; and 
(9)  Where applicable, serve to protect and preserve, as appropriate, individual buildings or grounds where there is special and substantial public interest in protecting such buildings and their visual environment. 
(Ord. No. 15-05-137, § 3.8(A), 5-5-2015) 
Sec. 35-512. - Nominations. 
(a)  Nominations to create a new special district or to amend the boundaries of an existing special district may be initiated by city council, the director or a minimum of 50 percent of the total number of properties within the proposed district subject to the approval of the director. 
(b)  Nominations by city council shall be in the form of a resolution requesting the director to prepare a recommendation. The nomination shall contain information and suggestions concerning the areas, buildings, and/or premises proposed for such regulations sufficient for the director to prepare a recommendation. 
(c)  Nominations by property owners shall be in the form of nomination applications to the director on forms provided for such purpose and shall be deemed to be complete at such time as all supporting required documentation has been provided. 
(d)  No recommendation on a nomination will proceed without a complete application. When an application is complete, the director shall prepare a recommendation to the planning commission and the city council. 
(Ord. No. 15-05-137, § 3.8(B), 5-5-2015) 
Sec. 35-513. - Recommendations. 
(a)  Recommendations concerning the establishment of a special district shall be prepared by the director for review. Favorable recommendations shall include an ordinance legislating creation of the district. Each favorable recommendation and associated ordinance shall identify the proposed zoning by the HM-SD prefix and a number generated by the director identifying the particular district, for example "HM-SD1." The identification may also include language indicating the character or location of the district. 
(b)  Such ordinance shall proceed for city council consideration in the same manner as any other similar zoning proposal. All such application shall be reviewed by the city council. 
(c)  The recommendation of the director (the "recommendation") shall contain the following items which shall be transmitted to the planning commission for its review. The recommendation shall be prepared only for the purpose of assisting in the evaluation of the special district ordinance and shall not become a part of the zoning ordinance. 
(1)  Comment on proposed district boundaries. The recommendation shall include a map indicating: 
a.  The boundaries of the special district and any subareas established within the district for purposes of special district regulations. 
b.  The location and designation of zoning districts or portions of districts, if any, to be supplanted by special district zoning. 
(2)  Staff report. Each recommendation submitted to the city council shall include a narrative staff report stating whether the director supports the proposed nomination of the district for special district designation, based upon whether the HM-SD regulations are appropriate for the nominated area, and may include such additional information and suggestions on the area, buildings and premises under consideration. 
(Ord. No. 15-05-137, § 3.8(C), 5-5-2015) 
Sec. 35-514. - Contents of the district ordinance. 
Each ordinance creating a special district shall contain the following: 
(1)  District boundaries. The ordinance shall include a map indicating the boundaries of the individual HM-SD district. 
(2)  Statement of intent. Each HM-SD district ordinance shall incorporate a particularized statement of intent appropriate to the individual district being created, establishing the purpose and justification for the creation of the district. 
(3)  Incorporation of general regulations. Each HM-SD district shall specify that the general regulations found in this chapter for HM districts are applicable to the HM-SD district created except to the extent authorized in subsection (4) of this section. 
(4)  Tailoring of regulations. Subject to this subsection, specific regulations may be established for each HM-SD district and such regulations shall be contained in the individual district ordinance. The individual district ordinance shall further specify when any of the below revised regulations apply to only portions of the HM-SD district and not the entire district as a whole. Specific regulations for an individual HM-SD district that revise the general regulations for HM districts shall be limited to the following: 
a.  The total number of large scale nonresidential uses may be revised. 
b.  Maximum block sizes may be revised. 
c.  Minimum and maximum parking calculations for HM districts in Table 35-401 may be revised. 
d.  Uses as listed in Table 35-595 permitted use table for the HM district may be restricted, limited or prohibited but shall not be expanded. Uses not allowed within the HM district in article VIII, division 2 shall be prohibited in all HM-SD districts. 
e.  Uses may be further limited by specifying the number of such uses, the size of such uses or the hours of operation for such uses. 
f.  Total acreage and lot size may be specified but shall not exceed the limitations of Table 35-461 for HM-SD districts. 
g.  Density and preservation open space for HM-SD districts in Table 35-461 may be increased or reduced. 
h.  The maximum amount of open space that may be transferred may be increased or reduced. 
i.  The district provisions for HM districts regarding primary facade setback, side yard setback, rear yard setback, building height, frontage buildout, civic space types and thoroughfare types may be revised. 
j.  Additional form, design, and/or landscaping standards may be established. 
(Ord. No. 15-05-137, § 3.8(D), 5-5-2015) 
Secs. 35-515—35-536. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 10. - SPECIAL DISTRICTS: INDIVIDUAL 

Sec. 35-537. - HM-SD1, Rico Crossroads Community Special District. 
The regulations set forth herein are the regulations for the HM-SD1 Rico Crossroads Community Special District. 
(1)  Statement of intent. The purpose and intent of establishing this HM-SD1 district is as follows: 
a.  Protect the existing old Rico commercial area from uses and building forms which are incompatible with the scale, character and needs of the surrounding area; 
b.  Preserve and restore existing, traditional and pedestrian scale buildings in this established historic commercial crossroads; 
c.  Promote historic small scale, local-serving commercial uses in established historic commercial crossroads; 
d.  Prohibit or place reasonable controls on the development of inappropriate large scale, highway-oriented retail, service, office and dining uses which are intended to serve larger areas of the city than the rural area of this community; 
e.  Alleviate development pressure on the surrounding rural area by placing reasonable controls on development and expansion of strip commercial uses, especially at the fringes of this district; 
f.  Facilitate safe, attractive and convenient pedestrian circulation and minimize conflicts between pedestrians and vehicles; 
g.  Encourage pedestrian flow through the design of buildings with ground level uses, that open directly onto sidewalks adjacent to public thoroughfares; 
h.  Establish building facade lines and sidewalk requirements, and reserve the space between buildings and the thoroughfare for pedestrian movement; and 
i.  Promote a nodal form of small scale historic commercial development that other zoning districts are unable to properly facilitate. 
(2)  Incorporation of general regulations. 
a.  The general regulations found in this chapter for HM districts are applicable to this district except where specific regulations are further established for this HM-SD1 district below. 
b.  Only the following uses shall be permitted, and only to the degree listed, for HM Districts in Table 35-595: 
1.  Agricultural uses. 
2.  Retail uses. 
3.  Services uses. 
4.  Office, professional as listed in technical uses. 
5.  Places of worship, as listed in arts, entertainment and recreation uses. 
6.  Restaurants and eateries, as listed in accommodation and food service uses. 
7.  Residential uses provided they are located in the second or higher story of a building. 
(Ord. No. 15-05-137, § 3.9(A), 5-5-2015) 
Sec. 35-538. - HM-SD2, Campbellton Crossroads Community Special District.

(1)  Statement of intent. The purpose and intent of establishing this HM-SD2 district is as follows: 
a.  Protect the existing old Campbellton commercial area from uses and building forms which are incompatible with the scale, character and needs of the surrounding area; 
b.  Preserve and restore existing, traditional and pedestrian scale buildings in this established historic commercial crossroads;

d.  Prohibit or place reasonable controls on the development of inappropriate large scale, highway-oriented retail, service, office and dining uses which are intended to serve larger areas of the city than the rural area of this community; 
e.  Alleviate development pressure on the surrounding rural area by placing reasonable controls on development and expansion of strip commercial uses, especially at the fringes of this district; 
f.  Facilitate safe, attractive and convenient pedestrian circulation and minimize conflicts between pedestrians and vehicles; 
g.  Encourage pedestrian flow through the design of buildings with ground level uses, that open directly onto sidewalks adjacent to public thoroughfares; 
h.  Establish building facade lines and sidewalk requirements, and reserve the space between buildings and the thoroughfare for pedestrian movement; and 
i.  Promote a nodal form of small scale historic commercial development that other zoning districts are unable to properly facilitate. 
(2)  Incorporation of general regulations. 
a.  The general regulations found in this chapter for HM districts are applicable to this district except where specific regulations are further established for this HM-SD2 district below. 
b.  Only the following uses shall be permitted, and only to the degree listed, for HM districts in Table 35-595: 
1.  Agricultural uses. 
2.  Retail uses. 
3.  Services uses. 
4.  Office, professional as listed in technical uses. 
5.  Places of worship, as listed in arts, entertainment and recreation uses. 
6.  Restaurants and eateries, as listed in accommodation and food service uses. 
7.  Residential uses provided they are located in the second or higher story of a building. 
(Ord. No. 15-05-137, § 3.9(B), 5-5-2015)

DIVISION 11. - HC, HISTORIC CROSSROADS DISTRICT[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 18-07-182, § 2, adopted July 3, 2018, set out provisions intended for use as div. 11, §§ 35-539—35-551. To preserve the numbering style of this Code, and at the editor's discretion, these provisions have been included as div. 11, §§ 35-550—35-562. 

Sec. 35-550. - Historic crossroads district. 
The regulations set forth herein are the regulations for the Historic Crossroads District. 
(1)  Statement of intent. The purpose and intent of establishing the HC, Historic Crossroads District is as follows: 
a.  Reconstitute historic crossroads communities as identified in the city's comprehensive plan and the future development map as viable downtown districts with authentic historic character; 
b.  Create walkable centers where people can live work, play and worship without requiring the use of a car; 
c.  Provide retail, service, and employment opportunities to the residents of Chattahoochee Hills and the surrounding communities; 
d.  Provide opportunities for incremental development within a defined framework of streetscapes and building form; 
e.  Provide opportunities for economic development; 
f.  Provide opportunities for recreation and neighborhood-oriented, neighborhood-friendly entertainment; 
g.  Provide opportunities for development densities that drive permanent preservation of rural land as defined in section 35-430, additional density; 
h.  Provide access to nature and opportunities to experience nature; 
i.  Prohibit or place reasonable controls on the development of inappropriate large-scale highway-oriented retail, service, office and dining uses which are intended to serve larger areas of the city than the rural area of this community; 
j.  Improve the quality of air and water in commercial areas through provisions for the planting of trees, greenspace protection, bicycle parking and electric vehicle parking; 
k.  Encourage a grid of connected thoroughfares to improve access and reduce congestion; 
l.  Facilitate safe, attractive and convenient pedestrian circulation and minimize conflicts between pedestrians and vehicles; and 
m.  To meet these needs in a fashion that supports the rural vision and brand as expressed in the city's adopted comprehensive plan. 
( Ord. No. 18-07-182 , § 2, 7-3-2018) 
Sec. 35-551. - Incorporation of general regulations. 
The general regulations found in this chapter for HM districts are applicable to this district except where specific regulations are further established for this HC district below. 
( Ord. No. 18-07-182 , § 2, 7-3-2018) 
Sec. 35-552. - Tailoring of regulations. 
The following specific regulations for the HC district revise the general regulations for HM: 
(1)  The following uses shall be permitted only to the degree listed for HM districts in table 35-595. All other uses shall be permitted to the degree listed for the RL district in table 35-595. 
a.  Agricultural uses. 
b.  Retail uses. 
c.  Services uses. 
d.  Professional services as listed in technical uses. 
e.  Places of worship, as listed in arts, entertainment and recreation uses. 
f.  Restaurants and eateries, as listed in accommodation and food service uses. 
g.  Residential uses. 
(2)  HM district open space requirements shall apply to all property in the district except single-family detached houses that are not a part of a master planned development. Up to 100 percent of the preservation open space requirement may be transferred off-site according to the rules found in section 35-271 (Transfer of open space requirements). 
(3)  Development controls table. The following table shall control the dimensional requirements of the HC district. All definitions and notes associated with the development controls table in section 35-461 shall apply. 

 
(4)  Rear yard setbacks for nonresidential uses shall be ten feet. Side yard setbacks for nonresidential uses shall be ten feet when adjacent to open space, and zero feet when adjacent to another nonresidential use. 
(5)  The district buffers described in section 35-272 shall not be required. 
(6)  The total number of large scale nonresidential uses as defined in section 35-359 (buildings and building areas) shall be zero. 
( Ord. No. 18-07-182 , § 2, 7-3-2018) 
Sec. 35-553. - Specimen tree preservation. 
A specimen tree survey shall be submitted with application for a land disturbance permit. The landscape plan should demonstrate the preservation of specimen trees to the maximum extent possible, including all specimen trees not within 50 feet of a building footprint or underground tank and not within 70 feet of a gas pump. 
( Ord. No. 18-07-182 , § 2, 7-3-2018) 
Sec. 35-554. - Landscape plan required. 
A landscape plan is required prior to the issuance of a land disturbance permit. The landscape plan shall be submitted for review by the city arborist and for approval by the director. Such landscape plan shall show the following, at a minimum: 
(1)  Existing and preserved specimen trees. 
(2)  Large shade trees shall be required every 40 feet along all thoroughfares. The applicant's landscape plan may redistribute trees in irregular arrangements where regular rows of street trees are not desirable, as approved by city council. 
(3)  Parking lot plantings as required in section 35-401(d)(8) 
(4)  A two-year landscape maintenance bond equal to 100 percent of the replacement value of the landscaping may be required by the city 
( Ord. No. 18-07-182 , § 2, 7-3-2018) 
Sec. 35-555. - Stormwater design. 
Stormwater features shall be designed as natural site features and integrated with the landscape as much as possible. All stormwater features shall be consistent with the Light Imprint Handbook. 
( Ord. No. 18-07-182 , § 2, 7-3-2018) 
Sec. 35-556. - Sidewalk requirements. 
Sidewalks shall connect every entrance and every parking area in the district with a pedestrian-friendly, easily navigable pedestrian network. Pedestrian lighting is required throughout. 
( Ord. No. 18-07-182 , § 2, 7-3-2018) 
Sec. 35-557 - Open space preservation. 
Land designated as open space in the HC district may share a lot with uses not listed on Table 35-265. Acceptable preservation mechanisms may be expanded to include permanent restrictive covenant, as approved by City Council. All other open space provisions are as described in Article VI, Division 4 of this chapter. 
( Ord. No. 18-07-182 , § 2, 7-3-2018) 
Sec. 35-558. - Establishment of form and design controls. 
The following regulations shall govern the form and design of development in the HC district: 
(1)  All structures and improvements shall be architecturally consistent with historic pre-World War II rural, crossroads, or small-town styles common in the Piedmont or southeastern region of the United States. Approval may be contingent on proof of such consistency, as determined by approval of the director, planning commission, and city council. 
(2)  Vehicular access shall be derived from internal thoroughfares and all buildings shall front internal thoroughfares. Both vehicular and pedestrian interparcel access shall be provided among adjacent properties. Driveways, parking lots, and pedestrian access shall be shared. Direct thoroughfare connections shall be provided for both vehicular and pedestrian access to adjacent HM, VL, or TN districts. 
(3)  Site design shall minimize cut-and-fill and maximize tree preservation in siting of buildings, drives, and parking facilities. The city arborist shall review tree preservation plans. 
(4)  Building height shall be limited to a maximum of 50 feet. 
(5)  First floor ceiling heights shall be a minimum of 14 feet 
(6)  Gas station canopies shall have pitched roofs, no shallower than 5:12, and shall be covered in shingles, shakes, or traditional standing-seam metal. 
(7)  All street frontages shall be detailed with street trees and street parking, along with architecturally-consistent street furniture, including pedestrian lighting, benches, trash receptacles, and bicycle racks. 
(8)  Buildings: 
a.  Materials. Exterior walls or facades shall utilize brick, glass, wood, stucco, stone or cement-based siding materials. Brick siding shall be painted or coated unless recycled brick or other antique finish is approved by the city. When used, lap siding shall be applied with a 4 ½ inch reveal. Materials and style should be consistent on all sides of the building. Exterior building materials shall not include smooth-faced concrete block; tilt-up concrete panels; prefabricated steel panels; highly reflective, shiny, or mirror-like materials; mill-finish (non-colored) aluminum metal windows or door frames; exposed, unfinished foundation walls; exposed plywood or particle board; or unplastered, exposed concrete masonry blocks. Material or color changes generally should occur at a change of plane. Piecemeal embellishment and frequent changes in material should be avoided. 
b.  Color. Paint colors shall be chosen from Sherwin Williams "Color Through the Decades" collections from 1850 - 1930 or the Benjamin Moore Historical Collection, or similar historical palette as approved by the city. Unpainted surfaces shall be muted natural and earth tones. Buildings should be a single color with a complementary trim color. Bright colors or franchise colors are permitted as accents only. 
c.  Windows and doors. Windows shall be vertical in proportion and topped with an appropriately-proportioned lintel or arch. Windows and doors shall be made of wood. Windows that are openable shall be double hung. 
d.  Roofs. Pitched roofs shall have pitches equal to or greater than 8:12, except that shed roofs on additions or porches may be shallower. Main roofs that are pitched shallower than 5:12 shall be enclosed by a parapet wall tall enough to screen the roof and the equipment on it, and at least 48 inches tall. The parapet wall shall be of a design and materials consistent with the building façade. Pitched roofs shall be traditional materials and treatments, appropriate to the historical style of the building. Facades should have a well-defined cornice with appropriate cornice returns on gabled roofs. 
e.  Doorways. Doorways shall be recessed unless under an awning or a porch with a depth of eight feet or greater. 
f.  [Historically accurate architectural elements.] Buildings shall include historically accurate architectural elements such as columns, arcades, covered entry-walkways, arches, facade offsets, windows, balconies, recesses. 
g.  [Exceptions.] Exceptions may be approved for design, color, or roof pitch when the application is accompanied with appropriate documented historical antecedents and approved by the city council. 
( Ord. No. 18-07-182 , § 2, 7-3-2018) 
Sec. 35-559. - Building permit review and approval. 
(a)  Architectural plans for all buildings in the HC district must be approved by the city council prior to the issuance of a building permit. 
(b)  Building permit applications shall be accompanied with color elevations accurately depicting materials, finishes, colors, etc. of all elements, including the primary structure, accessory structures, fences, awnings, and other appurtenances. Materials samples are encouraged to provide a better understanding of the proposal. 
(c)  City council approval of the final site plan is required before the issuance of a building permit. 
( Ord. No. 18-07-182 , § 2, 7-3-2018) 
Sec. 35-560. - Highway oriented retail alternative standards. 
(a)  Property with frontage on Cascade Palmetto Highway (State Highway 154) and buildings within 400 feet of the Cascade Palmetto Highway (State Highway 154) right-of way and within 700 feet of Campbellton Fairburn Road (State Highway 92) right-of-way may optionally follow the following alternative regulations. These alternative regulations shall be applied in addition to HC regulations, above, and all other regulations, except as specifically modified below. Developments utilizing the exceptions in (b), below, must also comply with the additional requirements listed in this section. 
(b)  The following exceptions from form and design controls apply only to property and buildings defined in (a), above: 
(1)  Maximum block face, block perimeter, and block area shall be eliminated. (Modifies 35-216 (e)) 
(2)  Surface parking and drives shall be permitted in front of the building (Modifies 35-401(d)and 35-359(d)(4)c) 
(3)  Parking maximums for retail and restaurant uses shall be increased to eight spaces per 1,000 square feet. 
(4)  Nonresidential Density Maximum shall be increased to 100% [modifies 35-541(c), above] 
(c)  Inter-parcel access for both vehicles and pedestrians shall be provided among adjacent properties. Driveways, parking lots, and pedestrian access shall be shared. 
(d)  Provisions for outdoor dining shall be provided for every restaurant use. Such areas shall meet the following requirements: 
(1)  They shall be landscaped and shaded by shade trees or awnings or the equivalent. 
(2)  They shall be connected to the restaurant by sidewalks a minimum of six feet in width. 
(3)  They are not required to be paved. 
(4)  They must include trash receptacles. Such receptacles must be kept in good condition and shall not be allowed to overflow. 
(5)  The amount of outdoor dining area to be provided shall me a minimum of 40 percent of the area of the indoor dining area. 
(6)  Provisions meeting outdoor dining area requirements may be shared among all restaurant uses on a site, provided that the total area required is not reduced. 
(e)  Sidewalks. 
(1)  Continuous sidewalks with a minimum width of six feet shall be provided along all road frontages 
(2)  Continuous sidewalks with a minimum width of eight feet shall be provided along all building frontages, including marked crosswalks across driving lanes, connecting all customer entrances. Where the sidewalks run parallel to parking spaces, they shall be treated as sidewalks above the curb with a minimum three foot wide landscaped area running parallel to the sidewalk, rather than as long crosswalks running across the paved parking surface. Alternative features such as boardwalks or continuous porches may be substituted as approved by city council. 
(3)  Building frontage sidewalks shall connect to the road frontage sidewalks at a minimum of one location per road frontage and a minimum of two locations per site. These connections shall be sidewalks with a minimum width of six feet and shall include marked crosswalks across driving lanes. Where these connections run parallel to parking spaces, they shall be treated as sidewalks above the curb with a minimum three-foot-wide landscaped area running parallel to the sidewalk, rather than as long crosswalks running across the paved parking surface. 
(f)  In addition to landscape requirements found elsewhere in this chapter, the landscape plan shall include the following: 
(1)  Evidence of parking lot landscape design that feels like cars in a park rather than trees planted in a parking lot 
(2)  Shade trees in landscape islands at the corners of each building 
(3)  A 40 foot wide planted rear buffer is required. Shade trees rising behind buildings mitigate the sense of barrenness that can come with expansive parking lots. The landscape plan should demonstrate that the site will be backed by a wall of greenery growing up behind the buildings. If site disturbance requires the removal of trees in the required rear buffer, it shall be replanted with a mix of large native overstory varieties, including at least 50 percent hardwoods. Provisions for inter-parcel connectivity for both vehicle and pedestrians may extend through the buffer. 
(g)  Bicycle infrastructure. The Campbellton neighborhood is a popular location for cyclists. Development of the HC district should provide the necessary facilities to serve users on bikes. These include bicycle racks at the main entrance to each building, vehicle entrances and exits designed with bicycle safety in mind or, preferable, a short multiuse path that allows bicycles to access the interior of the property without fighting vehicle traffic at the entrances and exits. 
( Ord. No. 18-07-182 , § 2, 7-3-2018) 
Sec. 35-561. - Limitation on locations of HC districts. 
The HC district may be located only where a Historic Crossroad is identified in the city's adopted comprehensive plan and where specifically shown on the future development map. 
( Ord. No. 18-07-182 , § 2, 7-3-2018) 
Sec. 35-562. - Example of architecture. 
Attached as exhibit "1" to this article is a drawing of the type of architecture that is to be incorporated and used in the HC districts. 
( Ord. No. 18-07-182 , § 2, 7-3-2018)

ARTICLE VIII. - USES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 35-570. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Accessory use means a subordinate use incidental to and customarily associated with a specific principal use, located on the same lot or parcel. 
Agriculture-related activities means agriculture-related activities that preserve the nature and character of agricultural areas including, but not limited to, the accessory use of land for slaughtering or processing of animals, petting zoos, educational tours, dude ranches, picnicking, pay fishing and pick-your-own vegetable and fruit gardens. Concentrated animal feeding operations (CAFOs) as defined by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency are not included in this definition. 
Air transportation; airport, private, means industries that provide air transportation of passengers and/or cargo using aircraft, such as airplanes and helicopters. See division 4 of this article for supplemental use provisions. 
Amphitheaters, small or natural, means amphitheaters and outdoor performance spaces designed for smaller performances or that are integrated into their natural surroundings with minimal impact. See division 4 of this article for supplemental use provisions. 
Amusement center means an establishment primarily engaged in operating amusements (mini-golf, go cart track, billiard parlor and game arcades). See division 4 of this article for supplemental use provisions. 
Amusement theme park means outdoor recreation facilities consisting of amusement rides, games, water slides, amusement vehicles, golf driving ranges, miniature golf, batting cages, water slides or any similar commercial outdoor recreation. Includes associated food service and indoor amusements. See division 4 of this article for supplemental use provisions. 
Assisted living facility means a facility having six or more beds and which offers accommodations that range from independent residential housing options to housing options with personal services. A residential use is to be considered an assisted living facility if it is registered with or licensed by the state as an assisted living home. Any dwelling, facility or structure which for any reason is not required to be or fails to be licensed by the state as an assisted living home, but provides housing, food service, and one or more personal services for any person and which also provides beds for six or more persons, who are not related to the owner or administrator by blood, marriage or adoption shall also be considered an assisted living facility. Personal services include, but are not limited to, individual assistance with or supervision of self-administered medication, and essential activities of daily living such as bathing, grooming, dressing and toileting. For the purposes of this chapter, a continuing care retirement community (CCRC) shall be considered an assisted living facility, and a "child caring institution" or "group-care facility" as defined in O.C.G.A. § 49-5-3 (as amended) with six or more beds shall also be considered an assisted living facility. See division 4 of this article for supplemental use provisions. 
Bed and breakfast, large, means a lodging establishment with six to ten bedrooms or a lodging establishment with less than six guestrooms when additional bedrooms or floor area are proposed or have been constructed in the 24 months preceding the application date. Bed and breakfast inns are characterized by a personalized service and inclusion of a full breakfast in the room rate. See division 4 of this article for additional supplemental use provisions. 
Bed and breakfast, small, means a lodging establishment with no more than five. Bed and breakfast inns are characterized by a personalized service and inclusion of a full breakfast in the room rate. A small bed and breakfast does not propose any additional bedrooms or an increase in floor area compared to what currently exists on the property, nor have any additional bedrooms or additional floor area been constructed in the 24 months preceding the application date. Proposals for additional bedrooms or floor area, or new bedrooms or floor area constructed in the 24 months preceding the application date, will qualify the establishment as a large bed and breakfast. See division 4 of this article for additional supplemental use provisions. 
Business means a use involving retailing, wholesaling, warehousing, outside storage, manufacturing or the delivery of services regardless of whether payment is involved. The term "business" does not include uses which are customarily incidental (accessory) to another use. 
Business service centers (including copy shops) means establishments generally known as copy centers or shops primarily engaged in providing photocopying, duplicating, blueprinting, and other document copying services, without also providing printing services (e.g., offset printing, quick printing, digital printing, prepress services) and establishments (except private mail centers) engaged in providing a range of office support services (except printing services), such as document copying services, facsimile services, word processing services, on-site PC rental services, and office product sales. 
Caterers means establishments primarily engaged in providing single event-based food services. These establishments generally have equipment and vehicles to transport meals and snacks to events and/or prepare food at an off-premises site. Banquet halls with catering staff are included. 
Cemeteries, mausoleums, colabariums means establishments primarily engaged in operating sites or structures reserved for the interment of human or animal remains and/or cremating the dead. 
Check cashing establishment means an establishment primarily engaged in facilitating credit intermediation (except mortgage and loan brokerage; and financial transactions processing, reserve, and clearinghouse activities) and licensed by the state pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 7-1-700 et seq. 
Clinic means a use where medical examination and treatment is administered to persons, including ambulatory patients, on an outpatient basis, with the facilities and equipment not being the most significant part of the production process. No patient shall be lodged on an overnight basis. 
College, university and professional school means any educational facility that provides training or education beyond the 12th grade, including, but not limited to, trade, business and vocational schools; any institution of higher learning or assemblage of colleges, affording instruction in the arts and sciences and the learned professions, and conferring degrees. Such facilities may also include uses related to energy production, room, board and food services related to the primary educational purpose of the use. 
Compost facility means a processing operation for the treatment of vegetative matter into humus-like material that can be recycled as a soil fertilizer amendment such as trees leaves and plant material. Organic animal waste, food, municipal sludge, solid waste, and other non-farm or non-vegetative type wastes are not included. See division 4 of this article for supplemental use provisions. 
Convenience store means establishments known as convenience stores or food marts (except those with fuel pumps) primarily engaged in retailing a limited line of food goods. 
Country inn means a facility, with the owner or innkeepers providing 24-hour-per-day on-site management, where guest rooms are made available for visitors for fewer than 30 consecutive days. A country inn is distinguished from a bed and breakfast in that it may have more than ten rooms and it may provide food service to the general public. See division 4 of this article for additional supplemental use provisions. 
Country market means establishments primarily engaged in the retail sales of food and beverages and other common household items merchandise from fixed point-of-sale locations. Establishments may have special equipment (e.g., freezers, refrigerated display cases, refrigerators) for displaying food and beverage goods. See division 4 of this article for additional supplemental use provisions. 
Data processing services means establishments primarily engaged in providing infrastructure for hosting or data processing services. These establishments may provide specialized hosting activities, such as web hosting, streaming services or application hosting; provide application service provisioning; or may provide general time-share mainframe facilities to clients. Data processing establishments may provide complete processing and specialized reports from data supplied by clients or provide automated data processing and data entry services. 
Day care center, adult; day care center, child, means a use in which shelter, care, and supervision is provided for six or less persons on a regular basis away from their residence for less than 24 hours a day. See division 4 of this article for supplemental use provisions. 
Day care facility, adult; day care facility, child, means a use in which shelter, care, and supervision is provided for seven or more persons on a regular basis away from their residence for less than 24 hours a day. A day care facility may provide basic educational instruction. The term "day care facility" shall include nursery school, kindergarten, early learning center, play school, preschool, and group day care home. See division 4 of this article for supplemental use provisions. 
Drive-through or drive-in means a facility or structure that is designed to allow drivers to remain in their vehicles before and during an activity on the site. Drive-through facilities are a type of site development that is usually found in conjunction with a quick vehicle servicing use or other retail sales and service use. Examples include, but are not limited to, drive-through windows, menu boards, car wash facilities, and quick lube or quick oil change facilities. 
Dump station means a place where raw sewage may be entered into a sewer system in a safe and responsible way, often used by owners of motorhomes, campervans, recreational vehicles or boats that are equipped with toilet facilities and a sewage holding tank. 
Dwelling means any building or portion thereof that is designed for or used for residential purposes for periods of more than 30 consecutive days. 
Dwelling, accessory, means a dwelling unit contained within an accessory structure or within a principal structure when separated from the principal use and served by a separate entrance. 
Dwelling, duplex, triplex or quadplex, means a structure containing two dwelling units (duplex); three dwelling units (triplex); or four dwelling units (quadplex). 
Dwelling, multifamily, means a structure containing three or more dwelling units not including townhouses. 
Dwelling, single-family detached, means one dwelling unit that is not attached to any other dwelling unit by any means. 
Dwelling, single-family zero lot line, means a single-family dwelling unit built to its lot lines or a portion of its lot lines that is also commonly referred to as a townhouse or rowhouse. See division 4 of this article for additional supplemental use provisions. 
Dwelling unit means one or more rooms contructed with the cooking, sleeping and sanitary facilities designed for and limited to use as living quarters for one family. 
Educational support services means establishments primarily engaged in providing non-instructional services that support educational processes or systems, including, but not limited to, educational consultants, educational testing services, educational guidance counseling services, student exchange programs and educational testing evaluation services. 
Farming, general, means a parcel of land which is used for the raising of animals (including fish) on a commercial basis, such as ranching, dairy farming, piggeries, poultry farming and fish farming; a facility for the business of boarding or renting horses to the public, or areas for the housing and riding of horses; the keeping and raising of all farm animals and fowl and use of private stables. Other uses include, but are not limited to, the establishment, cultivation, or harvesting of products of the field or orchard; the preparation and planting of pasture land; farm ponds; dairy operations; livestock and poultry management practices; the construction of farm buildings; the plowing, tilling, or preparation of soil at an agricultural facility; the planting, growing, fertilizing, harvesting, or otherwise maintaining of crops; the application of pesticides, herbicides, or other chemicals, compounds, or substances to crops, weeds, or soil in connection with the production of crops, timber, livestock, animals, or poultry; the breeding, hatching, raising, producing, feeding, keeping of livestock, hogs, equines, chickens, turkeys, poultry or other fowl normally raised for food, mules, cattle, sheep, goats, rabbits, or similar farm animals for commercial purposes; the production and keeping of honeybees, the production of honeybee products; and the keeping and raising of farm animals and fowl shall be subject to all regulations promulgated by the county health department. Concentrated animal feeding operations (CAFOs) as defined by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency are not included in this definition. On open space, the term "general farming" does not include animal feeding operations (AFOs) as defined by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency. 
Festivals or events, occasional, outdoor/indoor, means the periodic gathering of large groups of people for cultural performances, exhibitions, competitions, celebrations and similar events. See division 4 of this article for supplemental use provisions. 
Fitness and recreational sports centers means establishments primarily engaged in operating fitness and recreational sports facilities featuring exercise and other active physical fitness conditioning or recreational sports activities, such as swimming, skating, or racquet sports. Uses include, but are not limited to, tennis courts, neighborhood recreation centers, basketball courts, ice rink, hockey rink, soccer, field hockey and football fields, baseball and softball fields, gymnasiums, spas, group exercise and fitness centers, yoga, karate and similar facilities. See division 4 of this article for supplemental use provisions. 
Food processing and production means establishments primarily engaged in transforming livestock and agricultural products into products for intermediate or final consumption, including establishments that slaughter and prepare meats. The food products manufactured in these establishments are typically sold to wholesalers or retailers for distribution to consumers, but establishments primarily engaged in retailing bakery and candy products made on the premises not for immediate consumption are included. See division 4 of this article for supplemental use provisions. 
Forestry and logging means an operation on a tract or parcel of land involving the growing, conserving, and managing of forests and forest lands (includes the term "silviculture"). Forestry operations or practices include the raising and harvesting of timber, pulp woods and other forestry products for commercial purposes. The term "forestry and logging" does not include the cutting of timber associated with approved land development or the processing of timber into finished or semi-finished products or storage of logs other than temporary storage of logs harvested on the site. See division 4 of this article for supplemental use provisions. 
Fruit, vegetable and fresh food markets means establishments primarily engaged in retailing fresh, frozen, or cured meats and poultry; fresh, frozen, or preserved fruits and vegetables; or dairy products. Delicatessen-type establishments primarily engaged in retailing fresh meat are included in this industry. 
Funeral homes and funeral services means establishments primarily engaged in preparing the dead for burial or interment and conducting funerals (i.e., providing facilities for wakes, arranging transportation for the dead, selling caskets and related merchandise). 
Garage means an accessory structure for a residential use, designed or used for storing a vehicle or vehicles. 
Gasoline and fueling station means a use that provides for the sale of motor vehicle fuels and automotive accessories, and may provide minor repair and maintenance services. Such stations shall be limited to four or fewer bays excluding no more than one attached or detached bay for washing cars. The term "gasoline and fueling station" may also incorporate a convenience store. See division 4 of this article for supplemental use provisions. 
General freight trucking, local, means establishments primarily engaged in providing local general freight trucking. General freight establishments handle a wide variety of commodities, generally palletized and transported in a container or van trailer. Local general freight trucking trips are same-day return. 
General medical and surgical hospitals means establishments primarily engaged in providing diagnostic and medical treatment (both surgical and nonsurgical) to inpatients with any of a wide variety of medical conditions. These establishments maintain inpatient beds and provide patients with food services that meet their nutritional requirements. These hospitals have an organized staff of physicians and other medical staff to provide patient care services. These establishments usually provide other services, such as outpatient services, anatomical pathology services, diagnostic X-ray services, clinical laboratory services, operating room services for a variety of procedures, and pharmacy services. 
General warehousing and storage means establishments primarily engaged in operating merchandise warehousing and storage facilities. These establishments generally handle goods in containers, such as boxes, barrels, and/or drums, using equipment, such as forklifts, pallets, and racks, rather than bulk products of any type (regulated in open yard storage). 
Geographic antenna placement area means the general vicinity within which the placement of an antenna is necessary to meet the engineering requirements of an applicant's cellular network or other broadcasting need. 
Golf course and country club means a use of land for playing the game of golf; which may include a country club and a driving range as an accessory use. See division 4 of this article for supplemental use provisions. 
Governmental facility means a building or institution provided by the government to care for a specified need, such as a courthouse or county jail. 
Greenhouse, nursery and floriculture production means any land used to raise trees, shrubs, flowers and other plants for sale or transplanting. No more than ten percent of the income from the use shall be derived from the retail sale of related garden supplies such as chemical fertilizer, tools and other similar goods and/or equipment, and the retail sale of plants not grown on the property. 
Home occupation means an accessory business use of a dwelling unit in any zoning district. See division 4 of this article for supplemental use provisions. 
Hotel, motel or inn means a building in which lodging and/or boarding is provided for fewer than 30 days. The term "hotel," "motel" or "inn" may include an accessory restaurant and/or meeting and event facilities in conjunction therewith and may also mean tourist court, motor lodge and inn. See division 4 of this article for supplemental use provisions. 
Industrial launderers means establishments primarily engaged in supplying, on a rental or contract basis, laundered industrial work uniforms and related work clothing, such as protective apparel (flame and heat resistant) and clean room apparel; dust control items, such as treated mops, rugs, mats, dust tool covers, cloths, and shop or wiping towels. 
Interurban and rural bus or rail transportation means establishments primarily engaged in providing bus or rail passenger transportation over regular routes and on regular schedules, principally outside a single metropolitan area and its adjacent nonurban areas. 
Keeping and raising of farm animals does not include concentrated animal feeding operations (CAFOs) as defined by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency. 
Landscaping business means a business whose primary operation is the sale and/or storage of organic and inorganic materials, plants, mulch, pine straw, and other limited related accessory products for the landscape industry and the storage and use of associated landscape vehicles with an approved use permit for landscaping business, plant nursery, or garden center with indoor retail component. 
Libraries or archives means establishments engaged in maintaining collections of documents (e.g., books, journals, newspapers, and music) and facilitating the use of such documents (recorded information regardless of its physical form and characteristics) as are required to meet the informational, research, educational, or recreational needs of their user. These establishments may also acquire, research, store, preserve, and generally make accessible to the public historical documents, photographs, maps, audio material, audiovisual material, and other archival material of historical interest. All or portions of these collections may be accessible electronically. 
Livestock quarters and enclosures does not include concentrated animal feeding operations (CAFOs) as defined by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency. 
Manufacturing, heavy, means industries that create industrial products and/or vehicles by applying mechanical force to perform work, including forging, stamping, bending, forming, welding and machining. The term "heavy manufacturing" includes establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing rubber products from natural and synthetic rubber. Establishments manufacturing rubber tubing made from natural and synthetic rubber, regardless of process used, are included in this industry; other motor vehicle electrical and electronic equipment manufacturing establishments primarily engaged in manufacturing and/or building electrical and electronic equipment for motor vehicles and internal combustion engines. See division 4 of this article for supplemental use provisions. 
Manufacturing, light, means assembly and manufacturing of consumer products, including printing, but not including motor vehicles, or establishments that transform a basic fiber (natural or synthetic) into a product. 
Medical laboratory means establishments primarily engaged in providing analytic or diagnostic services, including body fluid analysis and diagnostic imaging, generally to the medical profession or to the patient on referral from a health practitioner. 
Mini-warehouse or self-storage unit means a structure or group of structures containing separate spaces/stalls which are leased or rented on an individual basis for the storage of goods. See division 4 of this article for supplemental use provisions. 
Mixed use means development with a mix of residential and nonresidential uses. 
Mobile food services means establishments primarily engaged in preparing and serving meals and snacks for immediate consumption from motorized vehicles or non-motorized carts. The establishment is the central location from which the caterer route is serviced, not each vehicle or cart. See division 4 of this article for supplemental use provisions. 
Mobile home means a structure, transportable in one or more sections, which is built on a permanent chassis and designed to be used with or without a permanent foundation when connected to the required utilities. For floodplain management purposes, the term "mobile home" includes travel trailers and similar vehicles placed on a site for 180 consecutive days or more. For all other purposes, including insurance purposes under FEMA-sponsored programs, the term "mobile home" does not include travel trailers and similar vehicles. A mobile home is not an industrialized home. 
Motion picture and sound recording industries means establishments primarily involved in the production and distribution of motion pictures and sound recordings. 
Motion picture theaters means establishments primarily engaged in operating motion picture theaters and/or exhibiting motion pictures or videos at film festivals, and so forth. 
Motor vehicle and recreational vehicle sales and rental means establishments primarily engaged in retailing or rental of automobiles and light trucks, such as sport utility vehicles, and passenger and cargo vans, and of vehicles used for leisure time activities and/or as a dwelling unit while traveling. Examples include a camper, a motor home, a travel trailer and a boat, or retailing these vehicles in combination with activities, such as repair services, retailing used cars, and selling replacement parts and accessories. See division 4 of this article for supplemental use provisions. 
Museums, historical sites, and similar institutions means establishments primarily engaged in the preservation and exhibition of objects, sites, and natural wonders of historical, cultural, and/or educational value. 
Nature parks and other similar institutions means establishments primarily engaged in the preservation and exhibition of natural areas or settings. 
Open yard storage means any activity which involves the sale or storage of any externally stored bulk material; the sale or storage, wrecking, dismantling, processing or sorting of waste, discarded or salvaged paper, rags, machinery, equipment or other junk, including automobiles, trucks and similar motor vehicles, including the temporary parking or storage of machinery utilized for heavy construction, earth moving, timber harvesting, tree or building maintenance, and other heavy, working vehicles; where those materials are commonly stored in an open area outside any building; provided, however, that businesses engaged predominantly in the repair or sale of new or used motor vehicles and other machines shall not be included in the term "open yard storage" if those vehicles and machines are in operating condition and ready for sale or, if non-operational, those vehicles or machines are stored in a building; any property with more than ten vehicles shall be considered open yard storage. Accessory office use of buildings on the property is not evidence that a use should not be considered open yard storage. See division 4 of this article for supplemental use provisions. 
Outdoor dining means the provision of seating on a portion of the sidewalk or lot outside of a business establishment for the purpose of eating, drinking, reading or otherwise socializing. See division 4 of this article for supplemental use provisions. 
Parking and storage of large vehicles means parking or storage of any vehicle in excess of 24 feet in length, eight feet in width or eight feet in height. See division 4 of this article for supplemental use provisions. 
Parking deck means a partially or fully enclosed building designed for the parking of vehicles. 
Parking lot means an unenclosed surface area used for the parking of vehicles. 
Pawn shops means establishments primarily engaged in providing non-depository credit (except credit card issuing, sales financing, consumer lending, real estate credit, international trade financing, and secondary market financing). See division 4 of this article for supplemental use provisions. 
Performing arts, spectator sports, and related activities (including amphitheater, stadiums and concert halls) means establishments primarily engaged in the organization and promotion of live presentations involving the performances of actors and actresses, singers, dancers, musical groups and artists, athletes, and other entertainers, including independent (i.e., freelance) entertainers and the establishments that manage their careers. See division 4 of this article for supplemental use provisions. 
Personal care home means any dwelling, facility or structure ("facility") required to be licensed by or registered with the state as a personal care home with no more than five beds is a personal care home for the purpose of this chapter. Any facility which for any reason is not required to be licensed by or registered with the state as a personal care home, or fails to be licensed by or registered with the state as a personal care home but which, through its ownership or management, undertakes for a fee or accepts a grant or utilizes its own funding to provide or arrange for the provision of housing, food service, and one or more personal services for two other persons, who are not related to the owner or administrator by blood, marriage or adoption shall also be considered a personal care home for the purpose of this definition. Personal services include, but are not limited to, individual assistance with or supervision of self-administered medication, and essential activities of daily living such as bathing, grooming, dressing and toileting. The term "personal care home" shall apply without regard to whether any fee charged is paid by the individual to whom the services are provided or by another person, the source of the grant, or the funding source for the operational costs and without regard to whether the facility is operated for profit or not for profit. For the purposes of this chapter, a "child caring institution" or "group-care facility" as defined in O.C.G.A. § 49-5-3 (as amended) shall also be considered a personal care home. See division 4 of this article for supplemental use provisions. 
Pet care services means establishments primarily engaged in providing pet care services (except veterinary), such as boarding, grooming, sitting, and training pets. See division 4 of this article for supplemental use provisions. 
Professional services means establishments primarily engaged in processes that specialize in performing professional, scientific, and technical activities for others, including, but not limited to, medical and dental services, legal advice and representation; real estate sales and rental agencies; financial services (not including banks, check-cashing and/or payday loans), collection agencies, accounting, bookkeeping, and payroll services; architectural, engineering, and specialized design services; computer services; consulting and counseling services; research services; advertising services; photographic services; publishing, print shops, translation and interpretation services; plumbers, exterminators, and other technical services; veterinary services; and other professional, scientific, office service, and technical services. 
Recreation center and club, private, means establishments primarily engaged in the private facilitation or provision of recreational amenities or opportunities. 
Recreation field means an outside area designed and equipped for the conduct of sports and leisure-time activities, including, but not limited to, softball, soccer, football, and field hockey, playgrounds, recreation areas, playing fields, and other similar uses or facilities. See division 4 of this article for supplemental use provisions. 
Recreational and vacation camp, RV park or campground means a facility which provides space, food and/or lodging facilities for social, educational or recreational purposes. See division 4 of this article for supplemental use provisions. 
Recycling center means establishments primarily engaged in collecting, sorting or processing materials to be recycled, including, but not limited to, plastics, glass, paper, and aluminum materials. Recycling bins shall not be included in this definition. See division 4 of this article for supplemental use provisions. 
Rehabilitation center means a facility providing on-site rehabilitative services whether operated for profit or not for profit. Onsite rehabilitative services include counseling services, therapeutic services offered as a part of any organized program for the mental, psychological, and substance abuse recovery. Uses such as halfway houses, drug rehabilitation centers or other facilities for treatment of drug dependency shall be included in this definition. The term "rehabilitation center" shall not apply to occupational or physical rehabilitation of any person, Hospitals or services located on the premises of a hospital or services offered to individuals by one or more licensed medical professionals in a private office setting or personal services offered as part of a permitted home occupation. See division 4 of this article for supplemental use provisions. 
Research and development means establishments primarily engaged in conducting original investigation undertaken on a systematic basis to gain new knowledge (research) and/or the application of research findings or other scientific knowledge for the creation of new or significantly improved products or processes (experimental development). 
Restaurants or eateries means establishments located wholly or partially within a building and primarily engaged in the preparation and serving of food to patrons. A cafeteria shall also be considered to be a restaurant. 
Retail, general, means establishments primarily engaged in the retail sale or rental of any merchandise not regulated elsewhere in this document from fixed point-of-sale locations, including, but not limited to, furniture and home furnishings; appliances and electronic products; building materials and garden equipment and supplies; food and beverages; health and personal care goods; clothing and accessories; sporting goods, hobby goods, books, and music; general merchandise; florists; jewelry; paint and wallpaper; office supplies, stationery and gift stores; used merchandise stores; pet and pet supplies and art dealers; etc. This industry also includes establishments primarily engaged in retailing a general line of new and used merchandise on an auction basis (except electronic auctions). 
Roadside stand means a use offering either farm-grown, prepared food products such as fruits, vegetables, canned foods, or prepared packaged meats or dairy products for sale from a vehicle or an open-air structure. The consumption of food on site is prohibited. See division 4 of this article for supplemental use provisions. 
Roominghouse or boardinghouse means a residential use other than a hotel or motel in which lodging may be provided to non-household members for periods of 30 days or longer, and which includes the provision of meals. See division 4 of this article for supplemental use provisions. 
Schools K-12, large, means establishments primarily engaged in furnishing academic courses and associated course work that comprise a basic preparatory education ranging from kindergarten through 12th grade for 100 or more total students. 
Schools K-12, small, means establishments primarily engaged in furnishing academic courses and associated course work that comprise a basic preparatory education ranging from kindergarten through 12th grade for less than 100 total students. 
Senior housing means a single-family or multifamily development intended for, operated for and designed to accommodate residents 55 years of age and older. Senior housing communities are designed for seniors to live on their own, but with the security and conveniences of community living. Some provide communal dining rooms and planned recreational activities (congregate living or retirement communities), while others provide housing with only minimal amenities or services. 
Services, personal and household, means appliance and home and garden equipment repair and maintenance, barber shops and beauty salons, garden centers; household, home, garden and pool services. 
Sexually oriented businesses means uses and activities regulated by the city licensing provisions and further regulated by this chapter. See division 4 of this article for supplemental use provisions.
